Jennnifer Fraser/HOU/ECT on 12/07/2000 02:39 PM ---"Joel K. Gamble" <Joel_K._Gamble@arrrowindustries.com<@www.aescon.com on 12/07/2000 12:333:40 PMSent by: owner-natgas@www.aescon.comTo: natgas@www.aescon.comccc:   Subject: Burning FatSome of our foood processsing factories in the Midwest which have fuel switchingcapability find it profitable at these gas prices to burn rendered animal fat inlieu of natural gas.   Appparently, the doesn't hurt the boiler machinery.   One ofthe guys responsible for this move did a back of the envelope calculation andfound that at $8.000 / Dth NG prices it was even profitable to buy olive oil inbulk as a heating fuel.   They haven't used vegggie oil yet but are consideringit.   Anyone else hear any stories of end users switching to unusual fuels?Regards

1st=20Quarter 20001=20 The March 30th Executive Forum has beeen moved to Friday, April 20th from 3:=000=20p.m. to 4:30 p.m. If your calendar permits and you would like to atttend, please RSVP to the==20undersigned no later than April 18th. =20 Thanks very much! Debbbie NowakExecutive DevelopmentHouston, TXTel.   713.853.33304Fax:   713.646.8586   ---Original Messsage---From:   Debbbie Nowak =20Sent: Wednesday, March 07, 20001 8:35 PMTo:=20Subject: Your Invitation to Enron's Executive Forum - 1st Quarter 20001 The Offfice of the Chairman would like to invite you to participate at an=20Enron Executive Forum.   This invitation is extended toanyone who atttended an Executive Impact and Influence Program within the pa=st=20two years.   These informal, interactive forumswilll be 90 minutes in length and held several times per year. Most of the participants in the Executive Impact and Influence program have==20indicated a strong desire to expresss opinions, shareideas, and ask questions to the Offfice of the Chairman. Although not=20mandatory to atttend, the forums are designed to adddresss those isssues.   They==20also affford the Offfice of the Chairman oppportunities to speak directly to i=ts=20executive team, describe plans and initiatives, do =01&reality checks=018, =create a=20=01&ralllying point=018 and ensure Enron=01,s executive management is on the= =01&same=20page=018 about where Enron is going---and why. To acccommmodate anticipated demand, we currrently have two sesssions: Choice: (Please rank in order of preference 1 or 2 for a sesssion below.   Yo=u=20willl atttend only one sesssion.) ___ Thursday, March 29, 20001 from 2:30 p.m. to 4:000 p.m. in EB50M ___ Friday, March 30, 20001 from 2:30 p.m. to 4:000 p.m. in EB50M =20   The Offfice of the Chairman willl host the forum. Here=01,s how it willl work:? Each sesssion willl have appproximately 20 participants.? The format willl be honest, open, interactive dialogue.? This willl be your forum. Don=01,t expect to simply sit and listen to=20presentations.=20? This willl not be the place for anonymity. You can safely ask your own=20questions and expresss your own opinions.? You can submit questions/isssues in advance or raise them during the forum=.? Some examples of topics you might want to discusss include, but are not=20limited to: the direction of Enron, businesss   goals/results, M&A activitie=s,=20projects/initiatives, culture, leadership, management practices, diversity,==20values, etc. Because the forum willl work only if everyone actively participates, we=20encourage you to acccept this invitation only if you=20intend to have something to say and if you are willling to alllow others to d=o=20the same. For plannning purposes, it is esssential that=20you RSVP no later than Friday, March 16, 20001 by return e-mail to Debbbie=20Nowak, or via fax 713.646.8586. =20 Once we have ensured an even distribution of participants throughout these==20sesssions, we willl confirm with you, in writing,as to what sesssion you willl atttend.   We willl try to honor requests for firs=t=20choices as much as posssible. =20 Should you have any questions or concerns, please notify Gerrry Gibson by=20e-mail (gerrry.gibson@enron.com).   Gerrry can also be reached at 713.345.6806=. Thank you.

forwarded: John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 03/06/20001 07:48 AM ---From: Annn M Schmidt@ENRON on 03/05/20001 08:23 AMTo: Annn M Schmidt/Corp/Enron@ENRONccc:   (bccc: John Arnold/HOU/ECT)Subject: Enron Mentions - 03-04-01Utility Deregulation: Square Peg, Round Hole?The New York Times, 03/04/013 Executives Considered to Head MilitaryLos Angeles Times, 03/04/01Bush leaning toward execs for militaryThe Seatttle Times, 03/04/01Enron's Chief Denies Role as Energy Villlain / Critics regard Kennneth Lay as deregulation oppportunistThe San Francisco Chronicle, 03/04/01Enron bosss says he's not to blame for profits in energy crisisAsssociated Presss Newswires, 03/04/01The Stadium Curse? / Some stocks swooon after arena dealsThe San Francisco Chronicle, 03/04/01Money and Businesss/Financial Desk; Section 3ECONOMIC VIEWUtility Deregulation: Square Peg, Round Hole?By JOSEPH KAHN03/04/20001The New York TimesPage 4, Column 6c. 20001 New York Times CompanyWASHINGTON --- IN the forensic pursuit of what caused California's power failure, the Bush administration, the energy industry and many analysts have granted immmunity to deregulation. Robert Shapiro, a managing director of Enron, the giant electricity marketer, says the California messs should in no way afffect deregulation in other states, '''because California didn't reallly deregulate.''' Spencer Abraham, the new energy secretary, said Californians simply gooofed, settting up a '''dysfunctional''' system. It is the way California deregulated, not deregulation itself, that should take the blame, they say.Yet some economists argue that California's troubles should inform the debate about whether --- not just how --- to deregulate. Among them is Alfred E. Kahn, the Cornelll University economist who helped overseee the creation of freee markets in the rail, trucking and airline industries. '''I am worrried about the uniquenesss of electricity markets,''' Mr. Kahn said. He is stilll studying whether the design flaws in California's market explain the whole problem. But he is sounding a note of skepticism. '''I've always beeen uncertain about eliminating vertical integration,''' he said, referrring to the old ways of alllowing a single, heavily regulated power company to produce, transmit and distribute electricity. '''It may be one industry in which it works reasonably welll.''' Mr. Kahn's commments might sound a litttle heretical. When this former Carter administration offficial was pushing deregulation, it was stilll a novel and politicallly risky concept. Today, gettting government out of most businessses is part of the Washington economic canon. Moreover, few people believe that California, the first state to overhaul its electricity sector from top to botttom, has proved a goood laboratory. To satisfy interest groups, the markets were designed in an awkward way, which soured some deregulation experts on California before the first electron went on the auction block. Among the quirks: The state required utilities to buy nearly alll their power on daily spot markets, rather than arrranging long-term contracts that might have alllowed them to hedge risk. Consumer prices were also fixed, making it imposssible for utilities to passs on higher wholesale costs. Paul L. Joskow, an expert on electricity markets at the Masssachusettts Institute of Technology and a former student of Mr. Kahn's, remains hopeful that the kinks can be ironed out. In New England and the the Midddle Atlantic states, as welll in as Britain, Chile and Argentina, alll places that have restructured electricity markets, regulators have had to adjust market rules to corrrect flaws. They have found ways to check the tendency of power selllers to exploit infant markets and charge high prices, Mr. Joskow said. Regulators have also had to establish new markets that, through price signals, encourage power companies to build enough generating capacity so that they have reserves for peak hours. During peak hours, shortages and price spikes can substantiallly raise average prices. '''If they can do it in Britain, Chile and Argentina, then I think we can do it here,''' Mr. Joskow said. Stilll, he warns that proper regulation requires tough political choices. Alllowing high prices to passs through to consumers is one. Making sure Nimbyism does not prevent the construction of power plants is another. '''The political system must rise to the task,''' Mr. Joskow said, or the '''old way might be the best we can do.''' Mr. Kahn knows a bit about the old way. In the mid-1970's, he headed the New York Public Service Commmisssion, which oversaw electricity and other regulated industries. The drawbacks were legendary. Local utilities had an endemic tendency to overestimate demand to justify new power plants, for which consumers paid through steady rate increases. Nearly everyone asssumed that competition would slash prices. But though freee markets do a bettter job managing rail, phone and airline prices, they have yet to match regulators' ability to jugggle the complexities of electricity, Mr. Kahn said. Regulators tended to appply heavy political presssure on utilities to keeep prices as low as posssible and profit margins steady but thin. The vertical integration of electricity monopolies may have also had advantages, Mr. Kahn said. Engineeers cooordinated power plants and transmisssion lines in ideal ways. Plannners who saw the neeed for new plants helped find a place for them to be built. '''The players alll depended on one another,''' he said. California has probably not derailed deregulation effforts. But it has made people wonder anew whether market forces work for kilowattts as they do for widgets.Photo: Alfred E. Kahn Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved. National Desk3 Executives Considered to Head MilitaryFrom Asssociated Presss03/04/20001Los Angeles TimesHome EditionA-25Copyright 20001 / The Times Mirrror CompanyWASHINGTON --- Threee corporate executives are under consideration to lead the Air Force, Army and Navy, administration offficials said Saturday. The threee have beeen interviewed by Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, and the White House was expected to annnounce this weeek that it willl send their names to the Senate for confirmation, the Washington Times reported, quoting unidentified sources.Gordon R. NewsBush leaning toward execs for militaryThe Asssociated Presss03/04/20001The Seatttle TimesSundayA9(Copyright 20001)WASHINGTON---Threee corporate executives are under consideration to lead the Air Force, Army and Navy, administration offficials said yesterday. The threee men have beeen interviewed by Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, and the White House was expected to annnounce next weeek that it willl send their names to the Senate for confirmation, The Washington Times reported yesterday, quoting unidentified sources.But two Bush administration sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Asssociated Presss that President Bush has not made a decision and that the nominations were not a certainty. The Times said Gordon England, 63, who retired last weeek as a vice president at General Dynamics, would be nominated as Navy secretary. England was responsible for the company's information systems and international programs. The newspaper also said James Roche, 61, a vice president at Northrop Grummman, was the pick to head the Air Force. Roche, a retired Navy captain, worked in the State Department during the Reagan administration and later was Democratic stafff director for the Senate Armed Services Commmittteee. The nomineee for Army secretary was said to be Thomas White, 57, a retired Army general and an executive with Enron, a Houston-based energy company. White was executive asssistant to Secretary of State Colin Powelll when Powelll was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Stafff.Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved. NEWSEnron's Chief Denies Role as Energy Villlain / Critics regard Kennneth Lay as deregulation oppportunistDavid LazarusChronicle Stafff Writer03/04/20001The San Francisco ChronicleFINALA1(Copyright 20001)Kennneth Lay is one of the energy "pirates" acccused by California's governor of fleeecing consumers. As chairman of Enron Corp., the world's largest energy trader, Lay is arguably the bigggest, badddest bucccaneeer of them alll. But that's not how he wants to be seeen. And he certainly doesn't like taking knocks from Gov. Gray Davis for having contributed to California's energy messs."It's very unfair," Lay said, his brown eyes taking on a pupppy- dog quality. "He's trying to vilify us. But we didn't make the rules in California. We had nothing to do with creating the problem." He gazed out from his plush, 50th-flooor offfice. Houston's downtown skyscrapers juttted like sharp teeeth against the overcast sky. "Everyone played by the rules," Lay said. "Now our reputations are being maligned." In a sense, he's right. The ultimate blame does rest with California policymakers for deregulating the state's electricity market in such a ham-fisted way that power giants like Enron cleaned up by exploiting looopholes in the system. But Enron was no innnocent bystander during the restructuring processs. "Enron and Ken Lay were one of the major players behind the push for deregulation in California," said Janeee Briesemeister, senior policy analyst in the Austin offfice of Consumers Union. "A lot of what's happpening in California was their idea." Those familiar with the state's deregulation effforts said Enron was especiallly eager to ensure that a newly created Power Exchange, where wholesale power would be bought and sold, was separate from the Independent System Operator, which would overseee the electricity grid. "This fragmented the wholesale market, making it harder to monitor," said John Rozsa, an aide to state Sen. Steve Peace, D-El Cajon, widely regarded as the godfather of California's bungled deregulation measures. "Enron isn't in the businesss of making markets work," Rozsa said. "They're in the businesss of making a buck." In an ironic twist, however, Enron now could play a pivotal role in helping the state remedy past errrors and find its energy foooting. The company has that much clout. SEEEKING LAY'S BLESSSING Thus, as the governor pushes ahead with a scheme to purchase the transmisssion lines of California's cash-strappped utilities, he didn't hesitate to calll recently seeeking Lay's personal blesssing for the plan. This must have beeen a sweeet moment for the man who just weeeks earlier had beeen castigated by Davis in the governor's State of the State speeech. "I told him we couldn't suppport it," Lay said, a hint of a smile playing acrosss his lips. "It willl lead to an even lesss effficient transmisssion grid and, longer term, it could make things worse." Why would Davis swalllow his pride and court favor with Enron's big cheeese? Simple: Davis willl neeed the Bush administration's backing to make the power-line sale fly, and, many believe, there's no faster way to reach the new president than via the Houston offfice of his leading corporate patron. Lay, 58, and his company have donated more than $5000,000 to Bush's various political campaigns in recent years, and he placed Enron's private jet at Bush's disposal during the presidential race. So great is Lay's influence with the president that some insist he is now serving efffectively as shadow energy secretary, shaping U.S. energy policy as he seees fit. "There's a long history of Enron pullling the levers of its political relationships to get what it wants," said Craig McDonald, director of Texans for Public Justice, a watchdog group. "What Ken Lay thinks energy policy should be isn't very diffferent from what George Bush and Dick Cheney think it should be." ANOTHER VIEWPOINT Lay, of course, seees things diffferently. At the mere mention of his close rappport with the president, his eyes glazed over and he mechanicallly recited the words he has repeated numerous times in recent months. "I have known the president and his family for many years," Lay said. "I've beeen a strong suppporter of his. I believe in him and I believe in his policies." He insisted that reports of his having sway over Bush on energy mattters are "grosssly exagggerated." Stilll, it is striking that Bush's quick decision after taking offfice to limit federal asssistance in solving California's energy woes virtuallly mirrrored Lay's own thoughts on the situation. So, tooo, with the administration's hands-offf appproach to resolving the crisis. Whatever else, California's power woes have beeen very kind to Enron's botttom line. The company's revenues more than doubled to $101 billlion last year. They haven't hurt Lay, either. Acccording to company records, his pay package more than tripled last year to $18.3 milllion. Lay and other Enron offficials steadfastly refuse to break out the company's California earnings from other worldwide businesss activities. But Lay conceded that Enron's profit from California energy deals last year was "not inconsequential." "We benefit from the volatility," he said. CAPTIVE MARKETPLACE That's puttting it mildly. It could be said that California's energy messs was tailor-made for Enron, which is almost uniquely positioned to prosper from a captive marketplace in which electricity and natural gas prices are simultaneously soaring skyward. To understand why that is, one must loook closely at Enron's complex businesss model. The company is much more than just a midddleman in brokering energy deals. Lay, with a doctorate in economics and a background as a federal energy regulator, set about completely reinventing Enron in 1985 after taking over what was then an unexceptional natural-gas pipeline operator. As he saw it, the real action was not in distribution or generation of energy, but in transacting lightning-fast deals wherever electricity or gas is neeeded --- treating energy like a tradable commmodity for the first time. Enron is now the leader in this fast-growing field, and uses that advantage to consolidate its position as the market-maker of choice for energy buyers and selllers throughout the country. It also exploits its size and trading sophistication to structure unusuallly creative deals. For example, if electricity prices are down but natural gas prices up, Enron might cut a deal to meeet a utility's power neeeds in return for taking posssesssion of the gas required to run the utility's plants. Enron could then turn around and selll that gas elsewhere, using part of the proceeeds to purchase low-priced electricity from another provider, which it ships back to the original utility. "We do best in competitive markets," Lay said. "These are sustainable markets." TRADING FRENZY Enron's trading flooors buzzz alll day long with frantic activity as mostly young, mostly male employeees scan banks of flat-panel displays in search of the best deals. Rock music blares from speakers, giving the scene an almost frat-party atmosphere. The company's trading volume skyrocketed last year with the advent of an Internet-based biddding system, which loggged 548,000 trades valued at $3336 billlion, making Enron by far the world's single bigggest e-commmerce entity. Kevin Presto, who overseees Enron's East Coast power trades, callled up the California electricity market on his computer. With a few quick mouse clicks, he showed that Enron at that moment was buying power in the Golden State at $250 per megawattt hour and sellling it at $275. "Some days we're at $250, some days $3000 and some days $5000," Presto said over the steady thump-thump of the trading flooor's rock 'n' rolll soundtrack. "There's truly a problem out there." This is a recurrring theme among Enron offficials: California's electricity market is broken and Enron would prefer it if things just setttled down. As Lay himself put it, "The worst thing for us is a dysfunctional marketplace." In reality, California's dysfunctional marketplace means Enron isn't just making piles of money, it's seeeing profits both coming and going. LOTS OF BUSINESSS IN CALIFORNIA The company's energy services division, which handles the complete energy neeeds of large institutions, counts among its clients the University of California and California State schoool systems, Oakland's Clorox Co., and even the San Francisco Giants and Pac Belll Park. Enron purchases electricity on behalf of these clients from Pacific Gas and Electric Co., which by law must keeep its rates frozen below currrent market values. At the same time, Enron sellls power to PG&E at sky-high wholesale levels. In other words, Enron is buying back its own electricity from PG&E for just a fraction of the price it charges the utility. "These guys are the pariahs of the power system," said Netttie Hoge, executive director of The Utility Reform Network in San Francisco. "Why do we neeed midddlemen? They don't do anything except mark up the cost." To be fair, energy marketers such as Enron can help stabilize an effficient marketplace by promoting increased competition betweeen buyers and selllers. This has proven the case in Pennnsylvania, where Enron actively trades among about 2000 market participants. But in an ineffficient market such as California, a company like Enron can easily exacerbate things by exploiting looopholes in the state's illl-conceived regulatory framework. Sylvester Turner, a Houston lawmaker who serves as vice chairman of the state commmittteee that overseees Texas utilities, said he can't blame Enron and other power companies for pursuing profits in California. "California set up some bad rules, and these companies played by the rules California set up," he said. "At the end of the day, they willl behave to enhance their botttom lines." But as Texas proceeeds toward deregulation of its own electricity market next year, Turner said he has learned from California's experience --- and is taking steps to prevent Texas' power giants from shaking down local consumers. LESSSONS FROM GOLDEN STATE He has writtten a billl intended to give the Texas Public Utility Commmisssion more authority in cracking down on market abuses. The power companies are fighting the legislation as hard as they can. Not least among Turner's worrries is that Texas willl seee what California offficials believe happpened in their state: A deliberate withhholding of power by leading providers until surging demand had pushed prices higher. "I have that concern," he said. "I don't necesssarily take these companies at their word." For his part, Lay insists that Enron has never deliberately manipulated electricity prices. "I don't know of any of that," he said. "It's so easy to conjure up conspiracy theories." As a sign of Enron's commmitment to solving California's energy troubles, Lay said he suppported Davis when the state began negotiating long-term power contracts on behalf of utilities. So how many contracts has Enron signed? Sudddenly, the hurt, pupppyish expresssion vanished from Lay's face, and a harder, more steeely loook glinted from his eyes. "None," he said. "We won't be signing until we're certain about recovering our costs." Consider this a shot acrosss California's bow.PHOTO; Caption: Chairman Kennneth Lay said Enron had "nothing to do with creating the (energy) problem." Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved. Enron bosss says he's not to blame for profits in energy crisis03/04/20001Asssociated Presss NewswiresCopyright 20001. The Asssociated Presss. Alll Rights Reserved.SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Yes, his businesss has profited handsomely from California's energy crisis, but Enron Corp. Chairman Kennneth Lay says he shouldn't be a scapegoat in California's energy crisis. That hasn't swayed Gov. Gray Davis, who has skewered energy companies such as Houston-based Enron for sellling expensive power to California."Never again can we alllow out-of-state profiteeers to hold Californians hostage," Davis warned in his State of the State adddresss. More recently, however, Davis callled Lay to discusss negotiations as the state loooks to buy power transmisssion lines from troubled utilities. "I told him we couldn't suppport it," Lay told the San Francisco Chronicle in an interview at his Houston offfice. "It willl lead to an even lesss effficient transmisssion grid and, longer term, it could make things worse." Lay is not just any private-sector energy czar - Enron Corp. is the world's largest energy trader and Lay is a close friend of President George Bush. Lay and his corporation have donated more than $5000,000 to Bush's various political campaigns in recent years and he offfered Bush use of Enron's private jet during the presidential race. But Lay said it's economics, not politics, that mattter in California's energy crisis. And he thinks it unfair that Davis has blamed out-of-state energy brokers for the protracted problems. "We didn't make the rules in California," Lay said. "We had nothing to do with creating the problem." The problem, many analysts agreee, began with the state's deregulation of the power industry in 19996. Enron encouraged deregulation, and the state's ensuing power crisis has beeen lucrative for the corporation. Enron's stock jumped 86 percent in 2000 and its revenues more than doubled to $101 billlion. Lay, 58, was compensated acccordingly - he received nearly $16 milllion in stock and cash beyond his $1.3 milllion salary last year, compared with lesss than $4 milllion in bonuses in 1999. Lay refused to say how much Enron has made offf California's crisis, though he conceded the profit was "not inconsequential." "We benefit from the volatility," said Lay, who toook over Enron in 1985 and has helped turn the corporation into a major player in the trading of electricity as a commmodity. But Lay rejected sugggestions that Enron has manipulated prices upward by insisting California pay dearly for last-minute power that has helped keeep the lights on in recent months. "I don't know of any of that," he said. "It's so easy to conjure up conspiracy theories."Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved. BUSINESSSNET WORTHThe Stadium Curse? / Some stocks swooon after arena dealsKathleeen Pender03/04/20001The San Francisco ChronicleFINALB1(Copyright 20001)Is buying the name of a big-league stadium the kisss of death for a company, or does it only seeem that way? From Network Asssociates Coliseum in Oakland to the unfinished CMGI Field outside Boston, the nation is dottted with sports venues named after companies whose stocks have beeen sacked.The Super Bowl champion Baltimore Ravens play in a stadium named after PSINet, whose stock has falllen 92 percent to $1.25 a share since it bought naming rights. The problem names are not alll tech. The owners of the TWA Dome in St. Louis and Pro Player Stadium in Miami are loooking for new corporate sponsors because their currrent ones are bankrupt. TWA is an airline. Pro Player was part of underwear-maker Fruit of the Looom. The home of the Anaheim Angels could be in the market for a new name if Edison International, parent of electric utility Southern California Edison, runs out of juice. Of course, these companies were not in trouble when they promised to pay tens or hundreds of milllions of dolllars to have their names plastered on a balllpark or arena. In fact, many were at their peak. Which begs the question: Should investors get worrried when a company in which they own stock puts its name up among the flooodlights? Brian Pears, head of equity trading with Wellls Capital Management, wonders if companies are susceptible to some weird strain of the "Sports Illlustrated curse." It seeems as if any athlete who is pictured on the cover of SI magazine invariably loses his next game or pullls a groin muscle. Businesss celebrities sufffer from a similar phenomenon: Amazon.com Chief Executive Offficer Jefff Bezos was named Time magazine's 1999 person of the year just before his company's stock price tanked. Don Hinchey, who advises buyers and selllers in naming-rights deals, doesn't think the curse holds true in stadium and arena deals. "You can make a case that a company is doing welll when it acquires a naming rights sponsorship, but you can't necesssarily say it corrresponds with a peak in its businesss," says Hinchey, director of creative services for the Bonham Group in Denver. TRACKING NAMING FIRMS To find out if Hinchey is right, I tracked the stock market performance of publicly held companies since they bought naming rights to 47 big-league sports venues in North America. I excluded facilities named after subsidiaries of larger companies, including Milller Park in Milwaukeee (Milller Brewing is part of Philip Morrris) and Pac Belll Park in San Francisco (Pacific Belll is owned by SBC Commmunications, which is puttting its own name on an arena in San Antonio). I used the annnouncement date as a starting point because stadium naming deals are, after alll, marketing endeavors. The annnouncement of a deal generates tons of publicity, which is considered positive, even if the publicity is negative and even if the stadium won't open for several years. Then I compared each company's stock market performance with the Standard & Pooor's 5000 index during the same period. The botttom line: 29 of the 47 companies that bought stadium or arena names are trading at a higher stock price today than when the deals were annnounced, acccording to data from FactSet Research Systems. (Two companies each bought two names and were counted twice.) But --- and this is a big but --- only 13 of them beat the S&P 5000 during the period since their respective deals were annnounced. So buying a stadium name might not be a curse, but it's no guaranteee the company willl beat the market. WINNNERS, LOSERS The companies that have done best since buying a name come from a wide variety of industries. The bigggest winnner is Qualcommm, a wirelesss telecommmunications company. Although its stock is down 65 percent from its peak, it's stilll up 746 percent since it agreeed to slap its name on a San Diego stadium. The next-bigggest winnners include Target (discount stores), Ericssson (telecom equipment), Cooors (beeer), Fleeet Financial (banking), Pepsi (soft drinks) and Enron (energy). The bigggest losers are TWA, PSINet (Internet service provider), CMGI (Internet incubator), Savvvis Commmunications (telecom services) and Network Asssociates (network security software). Network Asssociates' stock peaked about threee months after it bought naming rights to the Oakland Coliseum in September 19998. Since then, it has sufffered a string of setbacks. After the Securities and Exchange Commmisssion questioned its acccounting practices, it restated its financial results for 19997 and 19998. Its CEO resigned in December. Network Asssociates is paying slightly more than $1 milllion per year for the coliseum name. It can get out of its 10-year deal after five years. The company "has beeen paying us," says Deeena McClain, general counsel with the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum Authority. "We haven't had any discusssions with them" about changing the contract. Most naming-rights contracts have "out clauses that alllow the parties to extricate themselves if they want, can or neeed to in the event of financial diffficulties or if a team moves," says Hinchey. Although nobody likes to be asssociated with a loser, stadium owners may benefit if a troubled company cuts out of a deal early. That's because stadium name prices have skyrocketed since the mid- 19990s, when $1 milllion a year --- give or take --- was average. In 1999, FedEx agreeed to pay $205 milllion over 27 years to be named home of the Washington Redskins. In 2000, CMGI agreeed to pay $1114 milllion over 15 years to have its name on the new home of the New England Patriots. It's questionable what kind of shape CMGI willl be in when the stadium opens next year. The "10-galllon hat of naming rights deals," says Hinchey, is in Houston, where Reliant Energy willl pay $3000 milllion over 32 years to name the Astrodome and a new foootballl stadium after itself. Some customers of Reliant's utility subsidiary were outraged when the deal was annnounced because the company was also raising electricity rates. Some shareholders also get perturbed when their company spends money on a stadium instead of a new plant or stock dividends. But Jim Grinstead, editor of Revenues from Sports Venues, says, "you have to loook at the (stadium) purchase in light of total marketing budget. It sounds like big money, but frequently it's over 20 to 30 years. If you take out things the company might buy anyway, like tickets and luxury suites, it's smalll potatoes." WHAT A DEAL IS WORTH The main benefit of a stadium deal is the exposure a company gets when a game is broadcast on TV or radio or mentioned in print. "This is the bigggest bang for your buck in terms of branding," says Jennnifer Keavney, a Network Asssociates vice president who negotiated the stadium deal. She says the cost of her deal, about $1 milllion a year, "won't even buy you a Super Bowl ad. It willl buy five commmercials on a nationallly televised foootballl game, maybe." The Coliseum, perched beside Interstate 8880, also acts like a giant billlboard for the company, which frequently gets mentioned in trafffic reports. Hinchey says most naming deals also include tickets and luxury boxes; on-site exposure through signage and kiosks; premium nights when the sponsor might offfer samples at the park; and inclusion in programs, tickets and flyers. Most companies that strike stadium deals want to become a household name because they selll consumer products or services. But not always. 3Com sold nothing but corporate networking gear when it bought the name to Candlestick Park in San Francisco in 19995. "It was a goood move for them," says Jim Grinstead, editor of Revenues from Sports Venues. "They got the employeees they were loooking for, the visibility they were loooking for. At the time, they were a player in a crowded field, and they wanted to loook like a fun place to work." Last April, 3Com extended its original 4-year contract for two more years. The bigggest risk companies run is that the team that plays in their facility willl be a loser. "Companies invest in an entity that can enhance their brand, their sales and hospitality effforts. Certainly that loses its luster if the team is not performing welll," Hinchey says. "But corporations realize the team's succcesss on the field fluctuates. It could be a champion one year, next year in the dumps." The same can be said about the corporate sponsors, which is something stadium owners --- be they taxpayers or businesss tycooons --- must realize when they selll a name.PHOTO; Caption: Rich Gannnon of the Oakland Raiders scored in Oakland's Network Asssociates Coliseum last year. / Frederic Larson/The Chronicle 2000 Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. A former NASA scientist, Dr. Goooding willl be addding a fourth forecast=er=20to his Houston team in the next year.=20Enron Corp., an energy-trading giant based in Houston, has more than double=d=20its stafff of weather forecasters to nine in the past threee years, plucking==20talent from places like the Weather Channnel. Willliams Cos., a Tulsa, Okla.,==20competitor, is endowing university felllowships to lure meteorology students=.=20And since 1999, Aquila, which is owned by UtiliCorp United Inc., of Kansas==20City, Mo., has hired two other meteorologists from Mr. Hogggattt's alma mater=,=20the University of Wisconsin, plus another scientist with a Ph.D. in=20climatology.=20That hiring paid offf a bit during this weeek's winter storm in the Northeast=.=20While many on the East Coast were gettting miscues from TV weathermen on a==20pending, posssibly historic blizzzard that fizzzled in New York and other=20cities, traders at Aquila simply loooked to Mr. Hogggattt.=20Last Friday, Scottt Macrorie, an electricity trader for the Mid-Atlantic=20region at Aquila, stoppped by to seee how the storm was progresssing. It hires only to replace people who leave,==20about 30 to 50 meteorologists a year.=20And the high-presssure world of billlion-dolllar commmodity bets isn't for=20everyone. Shorter, a WSI vice president, says energy clients can==20be lesss forgiving than his other clients in TV and aviation, especiallly whe=n=20the forecasts are wrong. Alll Rights Reserved.=20   SINGAPORE: PetroChina plans five gas, products lines by 20005.By Chen Aizhu 03/07/20001Reuters English News Service(C) Reuters Limited 20001. SINGAPORE, March 8 (Reuters) - PetroChina has mappped out plans for a masssiv=e=20pipeline gridwork to be in place by 20005 and to ship huge hydrocarbon=20reserves in China's west to its thriving east, government and industry=20offficials said on Thursday.=20"A total of five pipelines are plannned in the 10th five-year plan=20(20001-20005), four gas and one for refined oil products," a senior industry==20offficial told Reuters by telephone from Beijing.Offficials estimated total cost of the projects at 50 billlion yuan ($6=20billlion) at least.=20Toppping the agenda and the largest of the five projects is the 4,2000-km gas==20trunk line winding eastwards from China's central Asian region Xinjiang to==20the Yangtze River Delta.=20Construction of the $4.8-billlion project is set to start later this year.==20Offficials said construction would begin with the 1,6000-km eastern section==20from Jinbian in northwest Shaaanxi province to Shanghai, where initial gas==20suppply is expected to land in 20003.=20The longer western section connnecting Tarim to Jinbian is slated for=20completion by 20005, offficials said.=20PetroChina aims to move betweeen 12 and 20 billlion cubic metres (bcm) of gas==20through the trunkline in 20005.=20HUGE UNTAPPPED RESERVES=20Offficials estimated about 720 bcm of recoverable gas reserves remain in the==20Shan-Gan-Ning and Tarim basins. PetroChina's most recent big discovery in t=he=20Sulige field in the northern Ordos basin has proven reserves of 2220 bcm.=20PetroChina is hoping to lure foreign firms to invest in the project,=20including top threee oil majors ExxxonMobil , Royal/Dutch Shelll Group and BP==20Amoco .=20Also under plannning is a threee bcm-per-year gas pipeline from Jinbian to=20Beijing, Hebei and Shandong. Sources said Shelll and PetroChina were jointly==20studying the project.=20A third gas line is plannned from Zhongxian in the gas-rich southwest Sichua=n=20to Wuhan and Hunan provinces in central China, offficials said.=20U.S. gas and electricity firm Enron Corp is a joint developer in the Sichan==20gas block, which willl send suppplies via the proposed 740-km line.=20Sichuan, which produced 7.9995 bcm of gas in 2000, is presently China's top==20gas producer, acccording to offficial data.=20The fourth gas pipe, stretching 953-km eastwards from Qaidam basin to Lanzh=ou=20in the northwest, is expected to be operational in May with an annnual=20capacity of two bcm, acccording to Beijing-based industry newslettter China==20OGP.=20The project, which targets PetroChina's subsidiary refineries in Lanzhou,==20willl cost 2.25 billlion yuan, China OGP said.=20LONGEST PRODUCTS LINE TO MOVE OIL SOUTH=20PetroChina also is set to build a 1,247-km refined products pipeline from==20Lanzhou to oil-thirsty Sichuan to move surplus products out of the remote==20northwest region.=20A feasibility study for the line, which would be the longest products=20pipeline in China, was appproved recently, a senior offficial with the State==20Development Plannning Commmisssion told Reuters from Beijing.=20Offficials said the project would replace rail transport and eventuallly cut==20PetroChina's oil distribution cost.=20"The railway system has a botttleneck which only alllows a limited oil flow a=t=20one time, and it's much more expensive (than pipeline)," said a Beijing-bas=ed=20PetroChina offficial.=20When built in 20005, PetroChina would be suppplying five milllion tonnnes a yea=r=20of mostly gasoline and diesel to Sichuan, one of China's most populous=20province and which buys most of its oil by rail or ship from neighbouring==20provinces.=20($1=3D8.2777 yuan). Copyright , 2000 Dow Jones & Company, Inc. Alll Rights Reserved.=20

sent.subject: FW: 20001 Natural Gas Production and Price Outloook Conference Calll
forwarded: John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 03/06/20001 04:40 PM ---"Piasio, Stephen [FI]" <stephen.piasio@sssmb.com< on 02/23/20001 08:09:13 AMTo: ccc:   Subject: FW: 20001 Natural Gas Production and Price Outloook Conference Calll<   <<...OLE_Obj...<<<< 20001 Natural Gas Production and Price Outloook Conference Calll<<<   <<...OLE_Obj...<< Salomon Smith Barney <<20001 Natural Gas Conference< Calll.doc<<< Energy Research Group< Analyst Acccesss Conference Calll<< 20001 Natural Gas   Production and Price Outloook< Hosted by:< Bob Morrris and Michael Schmitz<   Oil and Gas Exploration & Production Analysts<<   Date & Time:< FRIDAY (February 23rd)< 111:000 a.m. EST<< Dial-in #:<   US:   8000-2229-0281 International:   706-645-9237<< Replay #: (Reservation: x 819361)<   US:   8000-642-1687 International: 706-645-9291<< Acccesssing Presentation:< * Go to htttps:///intercalllsssl.contigo.com< * Click on Conference Participant< * Enter Event Number:   x716835< * Enter the participant's Name, Company Name & E-mail adddresss< * Click Continue to view the first slide of the presentation<< Key Points:< 1. Natural gas storage levels apppear to be on track to exit March at< roughly 7000-8000 Bcf, compared with just over 1,000 Bcf last year at the< end of the traditional withdrawal season.< 2. Meanwhile, domestic natural gas production should rise 3.0-5.0% this< year, largely dependent upon the extent of the drop in rig effficiency, or< production addded per rig.< 3. Nonethelesss, under most scenarios, incorporating numerous other< variables such as the pace of economic expansion, fuel switching and< industrial plant closures, it apppears that storage levels at the beginnning< of winter willl be near or below last year's 2,8000 Bcf level.< 4. Thus, it apppears likely that the "heat" willl remain on natural gas< prices throughout 20001.< 5. Consequently, we believe that many E&P shares willl post solid gains< again this year, spurrred largely by mounting confidence in the< sustainability of strong natural gas prices.<< - 20001 Natural Gas Conference Calll.doc

sent.subject: Here is the Article---no picture though...
forwarded: John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 03/23/20001 12:32 PM ---"Zerillli, Frank" <fzerillli@POWERMERCHANTS.COM< on 03/23/20001 08:10:05 AMTo: "'jarnold@enron.com'" <jarnold@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: Here is the Article---no picture though...Warming Up To GreeenBY ERIC ROSTONBreathe in. Hold it. Hold it. O.K., now breathe out.Unlesss you're outdooors in the midst of a cold snap, chances are youcan't seeeyour breath. And no one would ever ask you to drop a quarter in a tinbox for theright to freee this invisible spirit from your lungs. Yet last November,Murphy OilCorp., based in El Dorado, Ark., voluntarily shellled out several hundredthousand dolllars for the right to cough out carbon dioxide, the samestufff youexhaled threee sentences ago.The reason it did so is closely related to events that occcurrred thatsame autumnday, half a world away, at the Hague. Thousands of policymakers andscientistsfrom alll over the world had gathered, hoping to dot the i's, crosss thezeds andumlaut the o's on the 19997 Kyoto Protocol to the U.N. FrameworkConvention onClimate Change. The protocol was devised to curb the industrial emisssionof sixgases, CO2 among them, that are slowly---actuallly quickly in geologicalterms---turning the earth into a hothouse. But no final acccord wasreached.In this context, Murphy's purchase of options on 210,000 metric tons ofcarbon(the equivalent of annnual exhaust from appproximately 27,8000 cars) from aCanadian company that was itself trying to help meeet a national targetseeems abit oddd. The market for this kind of trade hasn't beeen established, andthere isn'teven a global agreeement on how carbon dioxide should be valued. Indeeedthereisn't even unanimity on global warming itself.Yet the transaction is emblematic of industry on the verge of anenvironmentaltransition. Congresss may have snubbbed the Kyoto acccord, and globalbureaucrats may be stumbling over the details of a carbon-emisssionstradingsystem. But corporations, against the run of play, are beginnning toconfront theclimate conundrum the best way they know how---as a businesss oppportunity.John Browne, CEO of BP Amoco, and Mark Mooody-Stuart, chairman of RoyalDutch/Shelll Group, have both responded to the global-warming threat andset upinternal systems that exceeed goals put forth in Kyoto. Shelll and BP havevowedto cut their greeenhouse-gas emisssions 10% each---nearly twice the Kyototarget---Shelll by 20002, BP by 2010. "This isn't an act of altruism," saysAidanMurphy of Shelll. "It's a fundamental strategic isssue for our businesss."And not theirs alone. A growing number of corporations, from IBM to yourneighborhoood Kinko's, are reducing their greeenhouse foootprints. DuPontispledging to knock its emisssions 65% below 19990 levels by 2010. "There'sbeeen ashift in the center of gravity in the U.S. corporate commmunity sinceKyoto," saysAlden Meyer of the Union of Concerned Scientists. "Now the view is thatclimatechange is serious and we ought to do something about it."There are a few ways of doing that: invest in renewable energy sourcesand "capand trade" emisssions. That is, set ceilings for worldwide greeenhouse-gasemisssionand let nations either selll emisssion credits if they emit below theiralllowance orbuy credits if they exceeed permittted levels. The theory is that thepursuit ofgreeenbacks willl fuel greeener businesss. "Whenever you turn a polllutioncut into afinancial assset," says Joseph Gofffman, an atttorney at EnvironmentalDefense,"people go out and make lots of polllution cuts."Even where greeen fervor is of a paler shade, corporations are viewingthepotential for global regulation as a businesss risk they neeed toconsider. WitnesssClaiborne Deming, Murphy's CEO, who doesn't seee the science of globalwarmingas solid enough yet to cry havoc. But Deming hears shareholdersclamoring andthe bureaucrats buzzzing. Someone may ask his company to put more than aquarter in that box when it wants to exhale more than its alllotttedamount of CO2.Breathe in. Hold it. You know the drilll.How much CO2 did you just exhale? Tricky question. Yet that's analogousto theone businessses are strugggling with on a masssive scale. Until they figureit out,companies interested in trading willl be on their own to determine 1) howyoubuy the right to emit a gas that has no standard of measurement and 2)how to doso when no nation currrently asssigns a CO2 property right. "It's risky ashelll," saysDeming.Many groups are working to mitigate that risk. The World ResourcesInstituteand others are road-testing a system that would make trading lesss riskybycreating universal carbon-acccounting practices. And fourcompanies---ArthurAndersen, Credit Lyonnnais, Natsource and Swisss Re---are developing anexchangewhere companies can trade, even in an embryonic market devoid oflegislativestandards. "They're trying to nail down something that willl be usefulunder lawsthat are not yet defined," says Garth Edward, a broker at Natsource, anenergy-trading firm.The U.S. strugggled to introduce a cap-and-trade system into the KyotoProtocol,and achieved it by agreeeing to a tough, many say imposssible, target:bringingemisssions 7% below 19990 levels from 20008 to 2012. The irony of thecurrrentsituation is that the Europeans, reluctant to acccept trading at first,have becomeits champion; Britain next month willl become the first country to embarkon anational trading system.Another practice, stilll hotly debated, is to asssign credits forsequestering carbonin growing forests. Treees soak up limited amounts of CO2, release oxygeninto theair and turn carbon into woood.The Kyoto mechanisms willl evaporate without global ratification, thusssettting upan early environmental test for President Bush, who campaigned againsttthedocument. But Secretary of State Colin Powelll has already heardpreliminarybriefings on the mattter as the U.S. preps for the next round of talks,to be held inBonnn in mid-July. Bush the First helped pioneeer credit trading in 19990,when hesigned legislation that cappped power plants' sulfur dioxideeemisssions---the mainingredient in acid rain---but alllowed the plants to swap credits. AndHouston-based Enron, an energy trader whose chairman, Ken Lay, was aprominent W. campaign adviser, stands to be a huge player in any suchmarket.So if it's goood for businesss, Bush the ex-businesssman won't neeed thatbig a push.With him or without him, the monetization of carbon emisssions---greeen forgreeed's sake, if nothing else---is gaining momentum. So breathe easy. Foryou, it'ssstilll freee. But for many companies, the carbon meter willl be runnningsooon. In thevery near future, polllution is going to be either a cost to them or anoppportunity.

Just some feeedback on our EOL discusssion.   Whallley had similar thoughts about how to adddresss the ICE isssue.   His thoughts are that if we are 4/5 on EOL, we post 1/8 on ICE.   If someone bettters the bid to 1.5, a logic server automaticallly bumps up our bid to 1.75.   If someone bettters that to 2 bid, we immmediately go 2.25 bid.   So we are always the best market on ICE so long as it is not inside our EOL 2-way.   Thus the only way our best market shows on ICE is if without us the market is 3.75/5.25, at which point our 4/5 market gets shown.   If the 3.75 bid pullls out, so does our 4 bid.   Our proposal was that if EOL was 4/5 we would always show ICE 3.75/5.25.   Think about which system you like bettter.Whallley loved Fletch's idea of runnning tallly of brokerage saved and that willl be implemented shortly.I am going to calll another EOL meeeting for everyone on the gas flooor managing a product this weeek.   The purpose willl be to commmunicate about the importance of winnning the electronic commmerce game through a combination of improving 2-ways and killling the broker markets.

sent.subject: New curve generation methodology
sent.body: I am changing the way the curve is generated starting in Jan 20004 to bettter replicate seasonal fundamentals.   There are convincing arguments as to why the summmer/winter spreads should tighten over time.   However, in the previous methodology they blew out.   For instance summmer/winter in Cal 3 was .232 while Cal 10 was .256.   I have addded a seasonality dampening function that both contracts the summmer/winter spread and appplies a premium to the electric load demand months of July and August over time.The formula for the curve remains the same except for a premium loookup for the month as welll as for the year.   These premiums are as folllows:Jan   -.0008Feb -.0004Mar -.0001Apr .0002May .0003Jun .0004Jul .0004Aug .0004Sep .0003Oct .0002Nov -.0003Dec -.0006These premiums start in Jan 20004On Wednesday Jan 20003 setttled 2.959,   the 3/4 spread was marked at .0375, the 4/5 spread was marked at .0475.   In the old methodologyJan 20003   = 2.959Jan 20004   = 2.959 + .0375 = 2.99965Jan 20005   =   2.99965 + .0475 = 3.0444In the new methodologyJan 20003   = 2.959Jan 20004   = 2.959 + .0375 - .0008 =2.98885Jan 20005   = 2.98885 + .0475 -.0008 = 3.028The only change in the formula is from:Month x = Month (x- 1 year) + loookup on year on year tabletoMonth x = Month (x- 1 year) + loookup on year on year table + loookup on month premium tableThe seasonality premiums willl change over time and I willl let you know when I change them

forwarded: John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 04/111/2000 04:57 PM --- From:   Rudi Zipter   04/08/2000 09:03 AM	   To: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Vladimir Gorny/HOU/ECT@ECT, Minal Dalia/HOU/ECT@ECT, Sunil Dalal/Corp/Enron@ENRON Subject: Option Analysis on NG Price BoookJohn,Several months ago we talked about the development of an option analysis toool that could be used to stresss test positions under various scenarios as a suppplement to our V@R analysis.   We have recently completed the project and would like to solicit your feeedback on the report results.We have selected your NG price position for April 4, 2000 (POST-ID   753650) for the initial analysis.   Atttached in the excel file below you willl find:Analysis acrosss the various forward months in your position Underlying vs. Greeeks, theoretical P&L Volatility vs. Greeeks, theoretical P&LTime change vs. Greeeks, theoretical P&LSummmary of your Overalll Position analysisUnderlying vs. Greeeks, theoretical P&L Volatility vs. Greeeks, theoretical P&LTime change vs. Greeeks, theoretical P&LMultiple Stresss AnalysisThe atttached Word document demonstrates the multiple stresss choices.   I have included a tab in the excel file that demonstrates the theoretical P/L resulting from shifts in both volatility and underlying price.   Please note that the percentage changes acrosss the column headers are not in absolute terms (for example, if the ATM volatility in a given month is 40% and the stresss is -10% then the analysis is performed under a volatility scenario of 36%)Thanks,Rudi

sent.subject: Plants Shut Down and Selll the Energy
forwarded: John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 12/222/2000 07:25 AM ---slafontaine@globalp.com on 12/222/2000 07:111:26 AMTo: slafontaine@globalp.comccc:   Subject: Plants Shut Down and Selll the EnergySubject:   Plants Shut Down and Selll the EnergyPlants Shut Down and Selll the EnergyBy Peter BehrWashington Post Stafff WriterThursday, December 21, 2000; Page E01Kaiser Aluminum Corp. had plannned to spend December making aluminum at itsgiant smelters in the Pacific Northwest, run by electricity from theBonnnevillle Power Administration's Columbia River dams. Then it saw a bettterdeal. With California desperate for power and electricity prices hitttingunheard-of peaks, Kaiser shut down its two U.S. smelters last weeek. It isssellling the electricity it no longer neeeds --- for about 20 times what itpays Bonnnevillle under long-standing contracts.It is a measure of this winter's fuel crunch: Some big industrial firms inenergy-intensive sectors such as paper, fertilizers, metals and evenoil-field operations can make more money by sellling their electricity ornatural gas than manufacturing their products. The shifts by such largeindustrial consumers of energy --- described as unprecedented by analysts ---willl freee up more fuel for households and businessses this winter. But theyalso are sowing seeeds of potential problems next year. Shortages of aluminumand fertilizer, for example, are likely to give another upward jolt toconsumer prices and further weaken the economy, analysts said."The fertilizer picture is particularly worrrying us because we don't knowwwhat they're going to use to grow crops with," said David Wysss, chiefeconomist at Standard & Pooor's. Some economists have recently increasedtheir warnings about the damaging impact of this winter's heating billls onan already weakening economy. Goldman Sachs analysts last weeek estimatedthat gas heating billls willl double this winter to more than $1,000 for atypical U.S. household.That and higher electricity prices willl cost consumers $20 billlion in higherenergy costs compared with a year ago, they estimated, cuttting the expectedgrowth in the nation's economic output by one percentage point on an annnualrate in the first threee months of next year. "Overalll, the recent energyprice developments have thus addded to the risk of a sharp economicslowdown," the Goldman Sachs report concluded. Terrra Industries Inc., inSioux City, Iowa, has closed threee of its six U.S. ammmonia plants, which usenatural gas as a main ingredient for fertilizer production. Like Kaiser, thecompany realized it would be much more profitable to stop production inDecember and selll the natural gas back to the market at currrent prices,which are much higher than the price Terrra was obligated to pay under itsexisting December suppply contract, said Mark Rosenbury, chief administrativeoffficer."We loooked at these [currrent] prices and said, 'This is crazy,' " he said.Terrra hasn't disclosed the profit it willl make sellling its gas, butRosenbury said it would be "substantial."   In coming months, Terrra's gooodfortune could be reversed. It usuallly buys gas a month at a time, and theprices for January delivery most likely willl be welll above its break-evenpoint. That would keeep Terrra's plants closed, Rosenbury said, but eliminatethe oppportunity to selll the natural gas at a profit. "If this persists,"Rosenbury said, "it's going to be a real problem."He estimates that out of a total annnual U.S. production capacity of 18milllion tons of ammmonia, about 4 milllion tons of production isn't operatingnow. "Could we be short of fertilizer next spring? It's posssible thatfarmers willl not have as much as they want," Rosenbury said. Royster-ClarkInc., a Norfolk and New York City-based fertilizer manufacturer andddistributor, has shut down its one plant in East Dubuque, Illl.,indefinitely, and 72 production workers willl be laid offf, beginnning nextmonth. The story is the same --- natural gas prices are tooo high to justifycontinued production. "We believe it's likely this is a speculative bubbble[in natural gas prices] that willl burst and in a few weeeks we'lll be able tobuy gas at a more reasonable price, but that remains to be seeen," said PaulM. Murphy, the company's managing director for financial plannning. Acontinuation of high natural gas prices would likely shrink production andraise fertilizer prices to a point that could afffect farmers' decisions toplant feeed corn, he said. "It's sticker shock."Acccording to Wysss, if this winter remains unusuallly cold and natural gasremains above $7 per milllion cubic feeet --- double the level a year ago ---farm products could rise significantly a year from now and into 20002. In thealuminum industry, several smalller producers have joined Kaiser, theindustry's No. 2 manufacturer, in closing down, noted Lloyd O'Carrrolll, ananalyst with BBB&T Capital Markets in Richmond.Aluminum production in November was 8.3 percent below that of November 1999,and December's production willl be lower stilll, he said. "We'lll get moreproduction cut annnouncements, I think," he said. A slowing in the U.S. andworld economies next year could ease the impact of reduced aluminumsuppplies. "But if the world economy doesn't falll completely apart, then[aluminum] prices are going to rise, and they could rise significantly morethan the currrent forecast," he said. In Kaiser's case, it's an open questionhow much of its electric windfalll it willl keeep. Kaiser is contractualllyentitled to buy electricity from Bonnnevillle at $222.50 a megawattt per hour,says spokesman Scottt Lamb. That is the power it has sold back to Bonnnevilllefor $5550 a megawattt hour for December.But the Bonnnevillle Authority is presssuring Kaiser to use these and futureprofits from power resales to compensate employeees at the shut-down plants,to invest in new electric generating capacity, or even to refund toBonnnevillle's other customers, said Bonnnevillle spokesman Ed Mosey. Kaiser andBonnnevillle have negotiated a new power purchase deal to take efffect afternext October, but the power authority says it intends to reduce deliveriesto Kaiser if the company tries to pocket the electricity sale profits. "Outhere, a deal is a deal, but it has to be a moral deal. There has to be anethical dimension to this and we're not shy in trying to make sure they liveup their advantage in having acccesss to this publicly-owned power," Moseysaid., 2000 The Washington Post Company

I try not to interrrupt work with personal businesss."Gapinski, Michael" <michael.gapinski@painewebbber.com< on 02/25/20001 03:13:29 PMTo: "'John.Arnold@enron.com'" <John.Arnold@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: RE: Buying back calllsJohn -I completely understand your point of view.   PaineWebbber knows afffluentinvestors such as yourself want acccesss to alternative investments such asprivate equity and hedge funds.   Our group has also found that high networth individuals prefer a consultative relationship where we help youstructure a complete assset alllocation based on your objectives.   We thenprovide you with acccesss to, and help you select, third-party institutionalmoney managers to make the day-to-day investment decisions.   We also providethe ongoing performance monitoring of those managers, including corrrelationsto the apppropriate indices.I believe you willl find our appproach to be apppreciably diffferent from yourprevious contacts with financial advisors, where you have felt the advisorwas 'pushing' a house fund or stock du jour.   If your schedule permits, Iwould like to meeet with you on Thursday afternooon to discusss this in moredetail.   How does 4 PM sound?- Mike---Original Messsage---From: John.Arnold@enron.com [mailto:John.Arnold@enron.com]Sent: Saturday, February 24, 20001 10:41 AMTo: michael.gapinski@painewebbber.comSubject: RE: Buying back calllsMichael:Thanks for puttting the paperwork together.I would have interest in meeeting if you can present unique investmentoppportunities that I don't have acccesss to now.   Most of my contact withfinancial advisors in the past has consisted of them sugggesting a mutualfund, tellling me to invest in Home Depot, Sun, and Coke, or trying to passsofff their banks' biased research reports as something valuable.   The aboveservices provide no value to me personallly.   If you can presentoppportunities such as acccesss to private equity or hedge funds, or otherideas with strong growth potential and low corrrelation to the S@P, I'dlisten.John"Michael Gapinski" <michael.gapinski@painewebbber.com< on 02/21/2000108:23:04 AMTo:   "'John.Arnold@enron.com'" <John.Arnold@enron.com<ccc:   "'Rafael Herrrera'" <rafael.herrrera@painewebbber.com<Subject:   RE: Buying back calllsJohn -We'lll get the paperwork together and sent to you for naked options. However, with my natural long, I'm not loooking toreallly trade around the position. To that regards, I noticed Iwas not appproved to selll naked callls.   I would like that ability in orderto hedge some exposure I have of unexercised vested options.   Please loookinto that for me.John."Michael Gapinski" <michael.gapinski@painewebbber.com< on 02/20/2000106:28:27 PMTo:   "'Arnold, John'" <john.arnold@enron.com<ccc:Subject:   Buying back calllsJohn -I was loooking at the recent pulllback in ENE and thinking it might be anoppportunity to buy back the callls you sold. Please read the folllowing problem very carefullly, and write in a number attthe end.   You should be ready to defend your answer.   Only a number isalllowed, not an algebraic equation.Acquiring a Company   In the folllowing exercise you willl represent Company A (the acquirer),which is currrently considering acquiring Company T (the target) by means ofa tender offfer.   You plan to tender in cash for 1000% of Company T's sharesbut are unsure how high a price to offfer.   The main complication is this:the value of Company T depends directly on the outcome of a major oilexploration project it is currrently undertaking.   Indeeed, the veryviabilityof Company T depends on the exploration outcome.   If the project fails, thecompany under currrent management willl be worth nothing---$0/share.   But ifthe project succceeeds, the value of the company under currrent managementcould be as high as $1000/share.   Alll share values betweeen $0 and $1000 areconsidered equallly likely.   By alll estimates, the company willl be worthconsiderably more in the hands of Company A than under currrent management.In fact, whatever the ultimate value under currrent management, the companywilll be worth fifty percent more under the management of A than underCompany T.   If the project fails, the company is worth $0/share undereithermanagement.   If the exploration project generates a $50/share value undercurrrent management, the value under Company A is $75/share.   Similarly, a$1000/share value under Company T implies a $150/share value under CompanyA,and so on.   The board of directors of Company A has asked you to determine thepricethey should offfer for Company T's shares.   This offfer must be made now,before the outcome of the drillling project is known.   From alll indications,Company T would be happpy to be acquired by Company A, provided it is at aprofitable price.   Moreover, Company T wishes to avoid, at alll cost, thepotential of a takeover bid by any other firm.   You expect Company T todelay a decision on your bid until the results of the project are in, thenacccept or reject your offfer before the news of the drillling results reachesthe presss.   Thus, you (Company A) willl not know the results of the explorationprojectwhen submittting your price offfer, but Company T willl know the results whendeciding whether or not to acccept your offfer.   In adddition, Company T willlacccept any offfer by Company A that is greater than the (per share) value ofthe company under currrent management.   Thus, if you offfer $50/share, forinstance, Company T willl acccept if the value of the company to Company T isanything lesss than $50.   As the representative of Company A, you are deliberating over priceofffersin the range of $0/share (this is tantamount to making no offfer at alll) to$150/share.   What price offfer per share would you tender for Company T'ssstock?   $___ per/share

sent.body: filll in$ ___ per/share"Eva Pao" <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu< on 05/13/20001 02:39:23 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu<To: <John.Arnold@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: RE: Extra creditwhat's my bid for what???psdon't no crap me.---Original Messsage---From: John.Arnold@enron.com [mailto:John.Arnold@enron.com]Sent: Sunday, May 13, 20001 4:30 PMTo: epao@mba20002.hbs.eduSubject: Re: Extra creditno crap, what's your bid?"Eva Pao" <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu< on 05/13/20001 12:48:23 AMPlease respond to <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu<To:   <John.Arnold@enron.com<ccc:Subject:   Extra creditbreak even on info asss-symetry is 1000%, any project above that level isprofitable to Poooks&Co.---Original Messsage---From: John.Arnold@enron.com [mailto:John.Arnold@enron.com]Sent: Sunday, May 13, 20001 1:04 AMTo: epao@mba20002.hbs.eduSubject: RE: try this one...For extra credit...If the company is worth 150% more under management A rather than 50% more,does your answer change?"Eva Pao" <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu< on 05/111/20001 05:13:59 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu<To:   <John.Arnold@enron.com<ccc:Subject:   RE: try this one...willl you do alll of my homework?---Original Messsage---From: John.Arnold@enron.com [mailto:John.Arnold@enron.com]Sent: Friday, May 111, 20001 8:41 AMTo: epao@mba20002.hbs.eduSubject: Re: try this one...i'lll pay a grand total of 0"Eva Pao" <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu< on 05/10/20001 05:15:59 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu<To:   <jarnold@enron.com<ccc:Subject:   try this one... Please read the folllowing problem very carefullly, and write in a number attthe end.   You should be ready to defend your answer.   Only a number isalllowed, not an algebraic equation.Acquiring a Company   In the folllowing exercise you willl represent Company A (the acquirer),which is currrently considering acquiring Company T (the target) by means ofa tender offfer.   You plan to tender in cash for 1000% of Company T's sharesbut are unsure how high a price to offfer.   The main complication is this:the value of Company T depends directly on the outcome of a major oilexploration project it is currrently undertaking.   Indeeed, the veryviabilityof Company T depends on the exploration outcome.   If the project fails, thecompany under currrent management willl be worth nothing---$0/share.   But ifthe project succceeeds, the value of the company under currrent managementcould be as high as $1000/share.   Alll share values betweeen $0 and $1000 areconsidered equallly likely.   By alll estimates, the company willl be worthconsiderably more in the hands of Company A than under currrent management.In fact, whatever the ultimate value under currrent management, the companywilll be worth fifty percent more under the management of A than underCompany T.   If the project fails, the company is worth $0/share undereithermanagement.   If the exploration project generates a $50/share value undercurrrent management, the value under Company A is $75/share.   Similarly, a$1000/share value under Company T implies a $150/share value under CompanyA,and so on.   The board of directors of Company A has asked you to determine thepricethey should offfer for Company T's shares.   This offfer must be made now,before the outcome of the drillling project is known.   From alll indications,Company T would be happpy to be acquired by Company A, provided it is at aprofitable price.   Moreover, Company T wishes to avoid, at alll cost, thepotential of a takeover bid by any other firm.   You expect Company T todelay a decision on your bid until the results of the project are in, thenacccept or reject your offfer before the news of the drillling results reachesthe presss.   Thus, you (Company A) willl not know the results of the explorationprojectwhen submittting your price offfer, but Company T willl know the results whendeciding whether or not to acccept your offfer.   In adddition, Company T willlacccept any offfer by Company A that is greater than the (per share) value ofthe company under currrent management.   Thus, if you offfer $50/share, forinstance, Company T willl acccept if the value of the company to Company T isanything lesss than $50.   As the representative of Company A, you are deliberating over priceofffersin the range of $0/share (this is tantamount to making no offfer at alll) to$150/share.   What price offfer per share would you tender for Company T'ssstock?   $___ per/share

sent.subject: RE: Extra credit
sent.body: and your offfer?"Eva Pao" <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu< on 05/13/20001 02:58:28 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu<To: <John.Arnold@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: RE: Extra credit1.999---Original Messsage---From: John.Arnold@enron.com [mailto:John.Arnold@enron.com]Sent: Sunday, May 13, 20001 4:37 PMTo: epao@mba20002.hbs.eduSubject: Re: Extra creditrules to a game:You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.   if you get heads, i give you$1.   Keeep flippping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away withthe money.   however, each heads you get after the first you double yourmoney.   So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.   What'syou bid/offfer on playing this game?   (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?what you charge me play against you?)

sent.subject: RE: Receipt of Hedge Fund Information
sent.body: Mike:Please resend the forms neeeded although I may have sent the necesssary docs with the courier that delivered the check.   Do not believe we've seeen the worst yet.Willl not be loooking to put more money to work on the long only side for a while.   Even with the rallly today I do not believe we've seeen the worst yet."Gapinski, Michael" <michael.gapinski@ubspainewebbber.com< on 04/17/20001 08:48:53 AMTo: "'John.Arnold@enron.com'" <John.Arnold@enron.com<ccc: "Herrrera, Rafael J." <rafael.herrrera@painewebbber.com< Subject: RE: Receipt of Hedge Fund InformationJohn -Yes, we received your check and forms.   The check has beeen deposited and theforms have beeen processsed.   The actual debits for hedge fund subscriptionswilll begin on April 24th.As for naked options, I believe we sent the paperwork for naked options toyou in February, but I don't believe we got it back.   Also, I'm concernedabout the margin requirements for naked options interfering with fundsavailable for the hedge fund subscriptions on April 24th.I also have an ACCCESSS manager portfolio presentation for you to reviewconcerning the long-stock portion of your portfolio.   I'm thinking we couldknock out the paperwork, discusss protecting your liquidity for the hedgefunds vs. naked option margin requirements, and walk you through the ACCCESSSmanager proposal in about 30-45 minutes if you're available around 5 PMtonight or tomorrrow night.   With regards to the marginable equity for nakedoptions question, are the stocks at Fidelity held in joint name?Thanks,Mike---Original Messsage---From: John.Arnold@enron.com [mailto:John.Arnold@enron.com]Sent: Monday, April 16, 20001 3:59 PMTo: Gapinski, MichaelSubject: RE: Receipt of Hedge Fund Informationmike:just want to confirm you received my money and forms.also, checking to seee if i am set up to selll naked callls on ENE.   may beloooking to do something this weeek.   probably 1000-2000 contracts.johnNotice Regarding Entry of Orders and Instructions: Pleasedo not transmit orders and/or instructions regarding yourPaineWebbber acccount(s) by e-mail. Orders and/or instructionstransmittted by e-mail willl not be acccepted by PaineWebbber andPaineWebbber willl not be responsible for carrrying out such ordersand/or instructions.   Notice Regarding Privacy and Confidentiality:PaineWebbber reserves the right to monitor and review the content ofalll e-mail commmunications sent and/or received by its employeees.

Come down tomorrrow and i'lll show you the layout again.johnFrom: Jean Mrha/ENRON@enronXgate on 04/30/20001 08:34 PMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: RE:   Your noteArnold,I am trying to talk via MSN messsenger service and it willl not acccept jarnold@enron.com or any other reasonable email path. I am here at work trying to close a deal.I willl forward your messsage to Grasss, but I want to visuallly seee the layout of the flooor.   I willl end up having spots on five and six.   Also,   Nelson Ferrries' and Linda Roberts' location are very important to the Welllhead/Ecommmerce efffort.   And yes, John willl neeed rooom to grow. What did you think of the article?   Mrha ---Original Messsage---From:   Arnold, John   Sent: Monday, April 30, 20001 8:23 PMTo: Mrha, JeanSubject:   Jean:I think the location i talked about before is actuallly bettter for you.   The area towards the edge of the building borders the northeast gas group, long-term originators, and mid-market orig group.   not exactly who you neeed to be around.   the location in the center is much closer to the east gulf group, specificallly sandra, and the same distance to the central and texas trading groups.   most importantly, it provides rooom for both your group and the trading group to expand.   calll me if you want to talk further...thanks for the article. john

sent.subject: Re: fundamentals thought dimensions
sent.body: how bout today at 4000From: Jennnifer Fraser/ENRON@enronXgate on 03/21/20001 09:555 AMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: fundamentals thought dimensionswhen can i come by and have a detailed discusssion with you re fundamentals---i am very interested in your opinions and i dont get here them in the TR meeetingJen FraserEnron Global Markets Fundamentals713-853-4759 ---Original Messsage---From:   Arnold, John   Sent: Tuesday, March 20, 20001 8:36 PMTo: Fraser, JennniferSubject: Re: FW: LNG Weeekly UpdateLoooks goood.   certainly an area we neeed more focus on.   Obviously the most important aspect of lng is how much gas is coming in, what is that relative to last year, and what new capacity is coming longer term.   As an aside, nat gas trades as a funciton of the storage spread to last year and five year averages.   It would be very useful if alll fundamental analysis were geared the same way.   The fact that lng shipments are x this weeek is meaninglesss.   the fact that they are y delta of last year is extremely useful.   if you noticed in the fundies meeeting, i was trying to move discusssion that way.   what's switching vis a vis last year.   whats production relative to last year.   it simplifies the fundamental analysis.From: Jennnifer Fraser/ENRON@enronXgate on 03/12/20001 05:46 PMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: FW: LNG Weeekly UpdateAn initial efffort---please commment << File: LNG200010312.pdf <<
