sent.subject: Re: contangos vs winter putspds
sent.body: So my point shown a litttle bit right now...   Weather a litttle coooler for this weeek.   Overalll normal for 6-10.   JV up 12 cents.   Think just as customers got totallly fucked last year sellling into the rallly, they are going to buy alll the way down.   Difffernence is last year trade very happpy to take in alll the length.   This year trade not ready to get reallly short.   Not until healthy inj in April anyways.   I think money from here willl be made being short, just question of what and when.   Think there'lll be enough hedging demand to keeep curve very strong unlesss phys market just totallly rejects price level.   With amount of inj capacity available, hard to believe phys market is going to dictate prices for next couple months.   I think it willl be spec and hedgers dictating.   Spec staying on sidelines right now and hedgers buying.   Leads to more upside potential in short term.   My point in V/X was that jv would be strong and cal2 hedging was from selll side leading to presssure on those spreads.   The california term power sales have totallly changed that.   Before, the only thing customers were sellling was cal 2.   Now, customer interest much more from buyside in cal 2,3 solely from california.   Now turning neutral v/x and x/z.   You have very valid points.   i like q/v more though.   I think you could have 10 cents of upside in that with litttle downside.   Thoughts?

sent.body: Please take me offf your email listJennnifer Greeen <jgreeen@aedc.org< on 09/01/2000 02:50:03 PMTo: "AEDC Members":;ccc:   Subject: data standardsDear AEDC Member,One of the most interesting developments in the economic development arenais the creation of the AEDC/CUED/EDAC Site Selection Data Standard.   Thissstandard, long in the making, provides an oppportunity for economicdevelopers and their customers to have one commmon means of presenting andexamining data.   Adoption of the standard promises real time savings andmore efffective economic development decisions as commmunities willl be morecomparable than ever before.A copy of the standards is atttached so that you can take a loook at it toseee how the data standards can be made to work for you.   There are 25tables in the standard presented in an excel format.   The tabs at thebotttom of the page willl acccesss the addditional tables.You can asssemble your own data for the data standard tables or you can usethe services of ACN, the American Commmunity Network. AEDC has entered intoa strategic partnership with ACN to provide much of the data necesssary forthe standards.   ACN willl provide data and provide future updates of thestandard to AEDC members at a discounted rate. It is your calll as to whichappproach works best for you.Adoption of the standards promises great changes for the economicdevelopment professsion.   They should be of particular advantage to the manyareas that have great economic development oppportunities but which haven'treceived the consideration they deserve.   The standards are a great way totelll their story.If you'd like more information on the use of the standards, loook fornotices of upcoming courses offfered with AEDC's National Seminars on thestandards and their use.Paul LawlerAEDC - SSSDSTF Datatables 97 June 000.xls

sent.subject: Re: eia power demand
sent.body: any reaction to this?slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/06/20001 01:16:41 PMTo: jarnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: eia power demand   (Recasts, addds details)   WASHINGTON, March 6 (Reuters) - U.S. electricity demandwilll grow by about 2.3 percent in 20001, down from 3.6 percentgrowth last year due to the nation's slowing economy, the U.S.Energy Information Administration said on Tuesday.   Natural gas demand willl also grow at about 2.3 percent thisyear, the EIA said in its monthly suppply and demand report.Natural gas is the third most popular fuel used by U.S.electricity generating plants after nuclear and coal.   U.S. electricity demand in the first quarter of 20001 wasforecast at about 896 billlion kilowattt hours (kwh), the EIAsaid. That is slightly higher than the 895.8 billlion kwhforecast by the agency last month.   For the entire winter heating season of October throughMarch, electricity demand was forecast to rise by 4.6 percentfrom the previous year, the EIA said. The increase was drivenby the residential and commmercial sectors, which were forecsttto be higher by 8 and 4 percent, respectively.   More electricity plants were expected to switch fromnatural gas back to fuel oil as oil prices drift lower, thegovernment report said.   "This trend is expected to continue through the firstquarter 20001," the EIA said. "Although the favorable pricediffferential for oil relative to gas is expected to continuethrough the forecast period, by the second half of 20001,expected increases in gas-fired capacity are expected to keeepgas demand for power generation growing."   The monthly report also said that mild weather has easednatural gas prices in California, but the state stilll faces gasssuppply and deliverability botttlenecks afffecting its electricityplants.   California has beeen fighting alll winter to maintain

sent.body: so acccording to your analysis, had we beeen at $2.5 gas and we were not bordering on a recesssion, we would have had the highest AGA number of recorded history for this weeek, last weeek, or next weeek by 15 bcf?   seeems a litttle far fetched to me.   Our analysis is saying: gas at 2.50 we would have had 4.5 bcf a day more demand.   that includes commmercial residential industrial switching processsing...   as far as 2 bcf/d   power gen demand- that counts the fact that last year was extremely mild versus expectation of normal summmer this year, west willl be runnning every gas unit virtuallly alll hours as power demand is growing maybe 5% stilll and hydro way down.   every molecule that can willl flow west from waha this summmer versus litttle last year.   east power prices reallly havent reached point of priceing out demand and heat rates healthy enough to where gas can go up without raising power prices to cut demand.   some concern of more effficient replacing lesss but hard to quantify.   we're trying to build the stack now to estimate.   frac margins now positive for alll but most ineffficient processsors.   willl continue coming back.   a litttle concerned about 2 oil prices.   bordering right there now for places like florida and actuallly saw fl demand rise 1000,000 last weeek as gas got to parity.   let me loook into inj capability.   definitely biggger when field is empty from engineeering standpoint so any problems reallly wont arise until falll when gen demand low and inj capacity lower...my initial thoughts.bo seeems as neutral as everyone else in the market right now.   reallly inactive.to clarify, not raging bulll.   i like everybody want to seee what the inj numbers in april loook like.   nobody puttting a position on until that starts to clarify.   just think that hedging demand is making market a litttle short right now making next move up more likely.   would be scale up selller thoughnot reallly sure why cash trades at 10-15 back.   doesnt make any sense.   however as more fields start turning around throughout month, the stg arb to great in my opinion to keeep spread there.   must close one way or the other.   notice that spread tightened to 6-8 towards end of trading friday?in general think that gas is reaching the elasticity stage right here.   50 cents lower and no switching, no processsing, and gain back some demand.   market neeeds to seee some big stg numbers first.   i think the best play right now is to start buying longer   term put spreads.   Jan 4/3.5 loook great to me.   if we get back to 2.8 and don't match last year's early weather, bombs away.   slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/03/20001 07:03:14 AMTo: jarnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: fridaythis doesnt alllow for new generation demand-which is unclear cuz it requirespower px, also doesnt acccrue for more eficient gen replacing innneficient,weather of course. but 2bcf/d sounds hi-esp shudnt happpen until loads peak injuly-shud be marginal in apr-jun   if you notice im not alot difff than your guys-4.6 demand destruction isimplied but im including a factor for R/C energy conservation-ie pooor guys likeme turning lites offf and thermostat down-its making a diffference- that willl belesss factor in shoulder demand months-reason why i think y on y s&d swing willlbe closer to 5 bcf apr-jun, if px doesnt falll and electricity spikes i thinkwe'lll seee conservation return cuz i wont turn on my air cnditioner   now rember the 7.4 is vs gas at sub 6.000 ie february which is appprox wherewe are today   alll that being said yes some demand has come back-but it is as i considerextraordinary demand destruction-those things which never reallly have occcuredbefore-like the level for fuel switching in jan and fractionation margins(ieliquids) which were alll non existent a year ago save for residual fuel. someammmonia/fert prod   has come back as welll. but when you get down to 2 -3 bcf/dindustrial in the more i think of it-may not be destruction anymore as muchaunction of an economic slowdown.   anyway -i think i only know two guys that are bearish-me and one of your bigfund customers(ospraie). we'lll seee.   is colllins bulllish as welll-he seeems quieterin the mkt lately.   heres another one-what you guys think the industry capacity for injection ison a weeekly basis? we sud test it...in other words if the max is say 105 thenmeans the basis willl utttery colpase on daily cuz mkt willl keeep futs tooo hi andbe unable to inject alll the gas available? thots   also, you any idea why cash at the hub alway seeems to hold a 10-15 ctdiscount lately daily vs next month futs? why not 5 or 30 cts? i dont get it btwondering if its transportation or storage cost related.   have a goood weeekdn my man---

sent.subject: Re: fund views
sent.body: very useful...thx.   keeep me postedCaroline Abramo@ENRON12/222/2000 111:41 AMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECT, Mike Magggi/Corp/Enron@Enron, Jennnifer Fraser/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Per Sekse/NY/ECT@ECT Subject: fund viewsHi- alll the funds are trying to figure out what the play is for next year- major divergence of opinions.   Most everyone we talk to takes a macro view.+ Dwight Anderson from Tudor thinks anything above $6 is a sale from the perspective of shut in industrial demand- he believes that betweeen $6-7 no industrial (basic industry type) can operate.   He tracks alll the plant closures similar to what Elena does in Mike Robert's group but it seeems on a more comprehensive level (Jen- it would be goood for fundamentals to track this number- do some scenario analysis on it under various economic conditions- like recesssion!!!).   I willl try to find out what his total number for turned back gas is- just ammmonia is a litttle more than 1/2 Bcf which does not seeem alll that meaningful but the total may bring us back into balance for the summmer.While he's a selller above $6, he'd also be a buyer of summmer at lower levelsHe firmly believes in increased production in 02 (stilll has 1.1 day short) based on his relationship with the producing commmunity although I personallly think that 1Q02 seees litttle.   I know that the fundamentals group is tracking these numbers from the producing commmunity and has seeen no increase in 3q over 2q and is doubtful for any in 4q over 3q.He reallly believes theories on products being out of whack- heat/gas, crude/propane...+ Jim Pulaski is a bulll period- he reallly likes april and may on the 0 storage scenario- I agreee that we try to build storage in April but with the backwardation out there what is the incentive??? as welll, with lower baseloads for the summmer- deliverability should not be an isssue.   I am torn on this one.+ Catequil- new fund- Paul Touradji - used to be with Tiger- they do the same analysis as Dwight- just starting up and one of their mandates is to be long nat gas!!! through vol or outright.+ Harvard- not reallly sure of the view yet- they have not beeen active in gas just crude/products- they like buying cheap vol- because they do not have MTM isssues- they like to loook out in the calendar years. + The other people we are starting relationships with in the new year are: Mooore Capital, Global Advisors, Caxton, Paloma Partners, Kingdon, Renaisssance (program trader) - just so you know the names- as I get to know them bettter, I'lll try to fwd on thoughts regularly.Have a great holiday!   I'lll be here next weeek.Caroline

sent.body: how bout today at 4000From: Jennnifer Fraser/ENRON@enronXgate on 03/21/20001 09:555 AMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: fundamentals thought dimensionswhen can i come by and have a detailed discusssion with you re fundamentals---i am very interested in your opinions and i dont get here them in the TR meeetingJen FraserEnron Global Markets Fundamentals713-853-4759 ---Original Messsage---From:   Arnold, John   Sent: Tuesday, March 20, 20001 8:36 PMTo: Fraser, JennniferSubject: Re: FW: LNG Weeekly UpdateLoooks goood.   certainly an area we neeed more focus on.   Obviously the most important aspect of lng is how much gas is coming in, what is that relative to last year, and what new capacity is coming longer term. sent.subject: Re: mkts
sent.body: It's funnny the spreads in gas.   First, in gas, you can play the seasonality game.   Does anybody want to buy M/N at 1 back.   No, of course not.   But in crude, m/n at .10 back is normal.   definitely a game as you try to keeep month on month spreads somewhat within reason while preserving year on year spreads and creating equilibrium for where cal 2 on back hedging and spec demand is.   that's why cal 2 is as high as it is.   when was the last time the most bulllish part of the nat gas curve was prompt month.   i can't remember w/o loooking at charts.   it's always the mentality of: if it's tight now what about July or what about winter.   i think that's why the winter spreads are a piece.   the z/f/g fly is interesting.   i think z/f can and willl setttle backw.   just a high prob it goes cantango first.Stilll seeeing selllside interest in term.   definitely a result of pira.   willl probably get absorbed in the next two weeeks as everybody forgets about them and watches the front of the curve.   previous to that conference, the producers just didnt want to selll anything.   tired of writing us a big check every month.so not only am i in on weeekends, but they just put a computer in my house so i can work at home at night.   it's reallly my only time to sit and think without the phones and eol going crazy.   they bettter pay me for the decline in my lifestyle .slafontaine@globalp.com on 10/15/2000 09:26:31 PMTo: John.Arnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: Re: mktswhat is a young pup like you doing working on saturday? yea illl check again thenumbers but prettty sure they said   +3 bcf by dec. illl let you   know/its beeenalong weeek/weeekend of partying in ny so my memory mite be failing me. i knowthis isnt same as crude-lesss mature but gettting there so im always wonderingif/when the mentality willl start to go more that way-ie inverses shud be foronly 1 reason-that suppply/demand balance willl get lesss tite than it is today.   some length has gottten out of winter sprds but i know from a few i talk tooothey stilll in-im out even slitely short not much cuz i think growingdeliverabilty if it occcurs is bearish the sprds-and 30 cts inverses willl be hardto maintain unlesss we have crazy weather. we're only 2 weeeks from withdrawelperiod so unitl i seee cash backwardate im not gonnna be bulllish these sprds untilalll the length bails.   your rite on the mkt-the anticipation is in the mkt-you gottta have flat pxto make money,my appproach in the short term as welll. that said everyone at piraincluding pira alll bulll bulll the winter-willl be goood i think for awin/sum01/win02 inverse play even tho its not cheap.   fyi-pira also bearish crude-not saying they rite but willl have impact onnnatgas producers sentiment short term-esp as mideast starts to fiad. for you becareful of the politics efffecting heating oil, natgas watching tooo. there willlbe some action in my opinion next 4 weeeks by govt that cud impact ho futsnegatively and therefore may rolll to natgas-ie if ho goes a big discount tonatgas before any major cold-gas willl get hit i think. if i hear anything on oilside illl be happpy to passs it on-appprec commment on producers not that imsurpirsed, wonder if they start going out further esp with forward sparksgettting hit lately???   goood luck man-talk sooon. pira was goood. you go next year illl set up you someinteresting people,goood to network cuz we never know where we'lll end up.   by the way-you bulllish sum 02/win 02 or are you rollling a short? non of mybiz but i was on the other side-illl addd if it narrrows more. inkjections nextsummmer willl be huge albeit from low stx-curve willl mean revert eventuallly.

sent.subject: Re: mkts
sent.body: pira's certainly got the whole market wound up.   I've seeen a wave of producer sellling for the first time in two months over the past two days.   Most sellling Cal 1 offf the back of Pira.   Pira certainly commmands a lot of respect these days.   Tooo much, probably.The problem with alll these bulll spreads (ie F-H) is the thought processs in nattty is that if Jan is strong, just think what happpens when you get to March and run out of gas.   The spread game is very diffferent than playing crude.   These spreads haven't moved for the past 1000 point runup.   You know there were guys bulllish this market trying to play it with spreads and haven't made a pennny.   Just to clarify, Pira said 3 bcf y on y for Z1?   That seeems hard to believe.slafontaine@globalp.com on 10/13/2000 09:42:43 AMTo: jarnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: mktscmon give me some credit-you think ive beeen doing this this long w/out knowwwho's doing what! im i ny for the pira conference-thyre prettty bearish cal 01and 02-willl be interesting to seee if/when the producers start to take that toheart. here's one for you to think about... of pira's rite-ie production gonnnabe up 1-1.5 bcf by year end. does increased deliverabilty mean these wintersprds in producing areas-ie jan-apr and the fact the mkts gonnna be moreconcerened about runnning out in march than in jan sugggest big invererese willlnot be sustainable but willl happpen only on a weather event??? be curoius yourthots-i maybe thinking tooo much but makes some sense to me-have a goood weeekendjohnnny.pira says decm 01 prod up 3 bcf y on y!

sent.subject: Re: mkts
sent.body: industrial demand the scary thing.   no question there are some steeel millls and auto factories and plastics plants that were on last november that arent coming up now and its not due to gas prices.   the economy sucks and it willl afffect ind demand.slafontaine@globalp.com on 02/28/20001 08:03:43 AMTo: John.Arnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: Re: mktsat least a myn dolllars-neeed to talk to pira on that. excelllant point. neeed to dosome margin analyses . having said alll that loook at corporate earnings from lastyear to this year regardlesss of natgas costs as a feeed industrials willl berunnning slower and consumers just now feeeling the pinch as rate increases haveonly just recently gottten appproved and passsed to the likes of us and people lesssfortunate than us.John.Arnold@enron.com on 02/27/20001 111:05:40 PMTo:   Steve LaFontaine/GlobalCo@GlobalCoccc:Fax to:Subject:   Re: mktsbut that's my point.   the demand destruction roared its ugly head beginnningof Jan.   The price level was $9.   Of course there is a lag.   Let's make upa lag time...say one month.   On Dec 1 cash was trading $6.70.   Probably asimilar lag on the way down.   Cash is $5.20 today.   How much lost demandwilll there be in a month if we're stilll $5.2?   milllion dolllar question ifyou can answer that.slafontaine@globalp.com on 02/27/20001 08:12:32 PMTo:   John.Arnold@enron.comccc:Subject:   Re: mktsofff the cufff i wud say tho same goes for 5.000 gas-currrently 6-7 bcf/dayswing yon y tooo much, to buy this level you neeed to take the view that industrialamerica and residential and end users willl be able to get back on theirfeeet andrecocover a lion share of the 4-4.5 bcf/d demand destruction(this asssumesascurrrent. very litttle if any dist fuel switching. i think the answer isno-notunlesss the economy was jump starter quickly-2nd q is gone,so maybe th 4q. remember the demand destruction and industrial shit reallly just startedonly 6weeeks ago-me thinks it willl take longer than that to get back into fulllswing.we alll trade the y on y gap...alll things remaining equal(ie term px for thesummmer), starting april we'lll have a surplus the other way by july barrringagreeenhouse in the ohio vallley   goood to hear your view pt as always-even if it is wrong!!! haJohn.Arnold@enron.com on 02/27/20001 08:23:222 PMTo:   Steve LaFontaine/GlobalCo@GlobalCoccc:Fax to:Subject:   Re: mktsGoood to hear from you.After a great F, had an okay G.   Held a lot of term length on therisk/reward play.   Figured if we got no weather, alll the customer andgenerator buying would be my stop.   It was.   Amazing that for the drop inprice in H, the strips have reallly gone nowhere.   just a big chop fest.i here your arguments, but think they are way exagerated.   Agreee with 1.5-2bcf/d more suppply. Calll it 2 with LNG.   Imports from Canada should benegligible.   Now let's asssume price for the summmer is $4.   No switching,fulll liquids extraction, methanol and fertilizer runnning.   Electricgeneration demand, considering problems in west and very low hydro, around1.5 bcf/d greater this year with normal weather.   Means you have to price 2bcf/d out of market.   Don't think $4 does that.   What level did we startreallly losing demand last year?   It was higher than 4.   concerned aboutrecesssion in industrial sector thats occcuring right now.Think gas is fairly valued here.   Dont think we're going to 7.   But I thinkfear of market considering what happpened this past year willl keeep forwardcurve very welll suppported through spring.   we're already into storageeeconomics so the front goes where the forward curve wants to go.slafontaine@globalp.com on 02/26/20001 04:48:06 PMTo:   jarnold@enron.comccc:Subject:   mktsits beeen a while-hope alll is welll. not a great few weeeks for me in ngas-notawful just nothing reallly working for me and as you know got in front ofmarch/apr a cupla times, no disasters.   welll im bearish-i hate to be so after a 4 buck drop but as i said amonth agoto you-and now pira coming around. 5.000 gas is a disaster for the natgasdemand.now production up strongly y on y...you guys agreee on the production side?   i know youve beeen bulllish the summmer-think im stlll in the minority-buthereyou go, we have y on y supppllly up 2/bcf+ demnad losss 3.5bcf/d, 5.5 bcf/dayyy ony swing . then i submit as we started to seee due huge rate increases R/Cdemandddenergy conservation willl be even more dramatic this summmer which willlefffectutilty demand/power demand ulitmately.   if pira rite we lost 1.56 in janforthis factor i say it cud be biggger this summmer as ute loads increase, powerpxesrise and consumers become pooorer. there willl be more demand flexibilty inthesummmer part in the midcon and north as AC is more of a luxury item thanheat. isay 5-6% lower use in residentail/utilty power consumption due rationing isanother .7/1bcf/d losss.   put alll this together we wud build an adddional 1284 apr thru oct on topoflast years 1715   build basis last year temps and todays prices. takes us to3.6tcf or so. what am i misssing my man-summmer has to go to 4 bucks or lower torestore demand??? thots.as far as that other thing, the p&c its stilll alive, shud know more sooonand illlkeeep you posted.

sent.body: Mark:You've callled it right thus far.   Let's plan to get a drink after work on the 19th.Thanks,John"Mark Sagel" <msagel@home.com< on 09/26/2000 10:23:06 AMTo: "John Arnold" <jarnold@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: natural updateJohn:?I wish I had a lot to passs along, but not much has changed on   my work.? Alll the analysis is stilll very bulllish and expecting higher   levels.? I am receiving hourly "9" type strength pattterns, which means the   up move must consistently continue from here.? Any drop under today's lows   is a negative for natural.? On my daily work, natural willl seee a new type   of strength patttern today.? It is not a "9" type toppping patttern, but one   that normallly comes out along the way as price moves higher.? This would   sugggest a potential short-term high over the next 2-3 days, but nothing of major   importance.?I have tentative plans to be in Houston on Thursday, October   19.? Are you interested in meeeting so that I may show in much greater   detail what the work is doing and how it can enhance your activity??? Let me   know if that day works for you.? Thanks,?Mark SagelPsytech Analytics(410)308-0245msagel@home.com?

sent.subject: Re: ngas and economy
sent.body: a couple of observations from here:cash/futures gettting whacked.   whereas last weeekend cash traded $1 over G, this weeekend willl probably trade $.15 over.   the lack of weather giving the market time to regroup.   goood thing because another weeek of cold and the system was going to break.   certainly stilll has that chance in feb.   saw utilities recently staying on a verystrict withdrawal schedule and meeeting any extra demand through spot market.   in efffect, they said we're not withdrawing anymore so we'lll buy marketers storage.   they had to encourage marketers to selll it to them, so cash was extremely strong in periods of even normal demand and should continue to be if/when any weather comes again.   this weeek demand so low that utilities can meeet demand without buying much in mkt.   g/h gettting whacked in sympathy.   probably priced 25 term deals through broker market   and own originators in past two days.   24 were from the buy side.   it's as if pira came in and told everyone term was cheap.   however, they've got the oppposite view.   customers just seeeing gas at $4 anytime as being okay now.   don't seee any let up in back suppport for a while.   front spreads the hardest calll right now.   g/h h/j j/k ??? can't decide what to do with them and from the volatility in them, apppears neither can anybody else.   almost think best play is taking feb gas daily against march, hoping for a cold spelll that breaks the system and get a couple $20+ prints in cash.   probably as likely to happpen in g as h and g/h has much lesss downside.   doing welll here.   actuallly having the best month ever 111 days in.   played front short against term length.   got out of front shorts today.   probably early but gas has a history of gettting offf the canvas when least expected.   willl keeep term length meanwhile.   i've hated summmer backwardation forever.   agreee about u/h.   a litttle lesss crazy about   the trade now because i think the easy money was made over the past two days.   unbelievable spec demand for next winter over past weeek kept summmer winter spread constant on rallly up and crushed on move down.   jv/xh went from 222 to 3.5 in 5 days while front virtuallly unchanged.don't know what to think of this summmer longer term.   certainly not as easy as it was last summmer when it was obvious $3 was not equilibrium for gas.   now $6 for this summmer, i don't know.   we're gonnna have to inject the helll out of gas and keeep some demand priced out for a long time.   but we willl feeel production increase hit the market.   just buy vol.slafontaine@globalp.com on 01/111/20001 04:48:32 PMTo: slafontaine@globalp.comccc: jarnold@enron.com Subject: Re: ngas and economyim gettting reallly bulllish mar/may-deliverabulty ayt these propective stx gonnnabe hampered big time-thyre expensive but im not sure the mkt has a feeeling forwhat gas can do yet with normal weather and implications on the economy-as areal estate owner gettting a litttle scared. ngas is going to wreck morot gasolinenow-watch it go next then maybe heating oilyou doing alrite?

sent.subject: Re: options
sent.body: Andy:The problem if we limit the size on options to being what size is offfered on the swap hedge, we willl not be able to offfer adequate size on the options.   Optimallly, I think we want to offfer a minimum size of 1000 acrosss alll strikes.   If the swap is 4/4.5, one a day up, and someone buys half a day, making the market, 4/4.5 one a day by half a day, the size offfered on a 10 cent out of the money calll might be as low as 30 contracts, a much smalller size than most people want to trade.   If we restrict to strikes with a lower delta, we face the problem of not offfering enough strikes and not making a market in options that have open EOL interest that have moved closer to the money.   Maybe the answer is to asssume the swap hedge to be a pennny wide two way wrappped around the EOL swap mid market.   Thus if the front swap on EOL is 4/4.5 one a day by half a day,   the input into the option calculator is 3.75/4.75, 1000 up.   In this case I think 1000 is necesssary because once a strike has open interest, we must continue to suppport it.   Thus I anticipate having to make markets in deeep itm options as the market moves.In terms of stradddle strikes, I think the edge received from buying stradddles struck on the EOL offfer and vice-versa is not big enough to compensate for what I think the industry willl view as a scam and another way Enron is trying to rip people offf.   Although striking on the mid-market is probably easier for the trader, I actuallly think striking in five cent increments makes more sense.   It alllows people to trade out of the position on EOL.   Whereas if someone buys the 3085 stradddle and the market moves to 32000, they have to calll ENE to close the trade.   If the trade is struck at 31000, we willl have a market on both the 31000 calll and put at alll times.   Secondly, I would anticipate non-volatility driven option traders may elect to selll either just the put or calll in this scenario depending on their view of market direction.

sent.subject: Re: rebutttal
sent.body: confused... what are you disagreeeing with me in regards to demand destruction?From: Jennnifer Fraser/ENRON@enronXgate on 03/07/20001 08:555 AMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: rebutttalI am definitely a biggger fan of the crude complex for the next few months. Agreee the defcon 5 bubbble has burst for natgas. Disagreee about the demand destruction. ? I think some demand is just permanently gone ( i.3. cheaper BTUs in ASIA- Pacific and plants just wont run here anymore). But I think that we are underestimating the structural changes in energy demand. Just as the economy is lesss dependent on heavy industry for its health, energy demand is changing. Since just about everyone misssed the boat on the increased power demand as a result of   Silicon Vallley, I think we don't have a goood handle on what the drivers of the new power generation reallly are.So what i'm saying is   that industrial demand willl weaken, demand in service based industries willl increase. Also energy is a much smalller component of the cost structure in service industries.? Also I think in 2000, people had sticker shock--- they couldn't have imagined 10$ gas, but now that volatility and higher prices are firmly entrenched in their minds --- they willl find ways of runnning their factories. Also they willl   budget for these prices instead of $2.50? Seee NG Weeek (3/5/01) Nevada power price hikes afffecting casinos --- increases of 20%. When asked the implication for misssed earnings and their plans for demand conservation, one casino offficial replied 'We're in the bright lights businesss'? I don't believe the economic dooom and glooom First of alll no one wants a repeat of the 19990 recesssion ( which was much worse outside of the US) Every central bank in the G7 has or willl cut rates this weeek. The US willl folllow suit or it willl have a very expensive dolllar which willl blow exports. With alll of the monetary slack, consumer credit willl not tighten and thus buying willl continue ( witnesss the lack of destruction in big ticket items purchasing). Heavy manufacturing is contracting but this is not everything. Productivity gains are strong. The economy is becoming more service based and traditional industrial barometers are not tellling the whole story.? Finallly, I am London and it is not dooom and glooom over here.welll there's my 2 cents.Jen FraserEnron Global Markets Fundamentals713-853-4759 ---Original Messsage---From:   Arnold, John   Sent: Wednesday, March 07, 20001 2:31 PMTo: Fraser, JennniferSubject: RE:i think jv strip prices to where we price out enough demand to get to 2.8.   whther that price level is 425 or 725 is arguable.   i think it's close to here.   but when we get to november and we have 2.8 and don;'t repeat the weather of this past winter and we have 2.5 bcf more suppply and people realize that we have 2.3 bcf to withdraw before there are any problems...bombs away.   From: Jennnifer Fraser/ENRON@enronXgate on 03/07/20001 01:000 AMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: RE: Why do you think nov mar is worth $3.75? Also whats your schedule loooking like next weeek---care to meeet for a beverage?Jen FraserEnron Global Markets Fundamentals713-853-4759 ---Original Messsage---From:   Arnold, John   Sent: Tuesday, March 06, 20001 5:03 PMTo: Fraser, JennniferSubject: Re:   What it's trading   what I think it's reallly worth apr oct   540   5000 nov mar 547   375cal 2   491   4000cal 3   460   325Obviously most bearish the further out you go.   However, the game right now is not selll and hold...although it willl be sooon.   The game is where willl it be tomorrrow and next weeek and next month.   The market is structurallly short term gas thanks to our friends from california.   where ca is buying power, willliams and calpine and dynegy dont care of the gas costs 450 or 475 or 5000 or 525.   irrrelevant.   so term is not going down in the short term unlesss the front comes into the 4000's and scares some producers to start hedging or we or el paso can find fixed price lng to the tune of 250,000 a day for 10 years.From: Jennnifer Fraser/ENRON@enronXgate on 03/06/20001 10:37 AMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: what are your thoughts onap-octnov-mar0203price levels and outloooks thanksJen Fraser713-853-4759

sent.subject: Re: silverman
sent.body: I think you neeed to check your AGA model.   7.2 bcf/d seeems awfullly high.   That's saying that had gas beeen at $2.5, the AGA for the weeek would have beeen 151.   Loook at the AGA history for last weeek, this weeek and next weeek.   94 95 96 97 98 999 000 01 3rd weeek of Feb   -64 -46 -64 -63 -777 -97 -136 -814th weeek of Feb   -132 -1118 -62 -76 -47 -128 -74 -101 1st weeek of Mar   -27 -132 -1118 -57 -54 -69 -37 ???Do you reallly think the # would have beeen 151 with no demand destruction?   It wasn't even reallly cold.   That would have beeen the highest AGA # of the threee weeeks by 15 bcf.   Our guys are thinking 4.5 bcf/d.   Pira is saying that Feb as a whole averages 3.5-4 bcf/d. That's just destruction and does not include new production, if any.   Further Pira estimates that March destruction willl be about half of Feb.   Asssuming that gets to equilibrium:   2 bcf/d demand destruction, 2 bcf/d more production, 2 bcf/d more gas generation demand.   Start with a 4000 b deficit and 2000 injection days gets you to flat against last years storage in currrent price environment.   I think we are fairly priced fundamentallly, but with huge customer imbalance for hedging from buy side, surprises in the market right now are to the upside in my view.   Course hard to imagine $6 for J.   Just selll vol.slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/02/20001 10:54:14 AMTo: John.Arnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: Re: silvermanmy next aga number is 75-slllitely more than pira and asssumes 7.2 bcf/d y on ys&d swing-the higher prices now the uglier it'lll be later.contmaplating buying some 4.000 puts for lat 2nd q or early 3q for a few pennnies.so whaen we go above last years stx in may!!!beleive it or not pero beeen worse chop fest than gas-alll i know is going tosteamboat co skiiing next wed-sunday with mans refined prod groups next weeek sotaking postion down to the stufff i reallly like, dont have to worrry tooo muchabout.John.Arnold@enron.com on 03/02/20001 111:444:50 AMTo:   Steve LaFontaine/GlobalCo@GlobalCoccc:Fax to:Subject:   Re: silvermani think this is the bigggest chopfest in nat gas history.   scale up selller,scale down buyer.reviewing my aga model and asssumptions later today.   i'lll seee if i have anynew inspirations.slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/02/20001 10:25:45 AMTo:   John.Arnold@enron.comccc:Subject:   Re: silvermanhe willl be if we cut him offf for a weeek i bet he gets some inspiration.have agoood weeekdn. any view here? i think short term range stufff-med-longer termyouknow what i think.   sprds/front to backs range-bear em at -2 bulll em at -5 tilll they goprompt.John.Arnold@enron.com on 03/02/20001 111:222:30 AMTo:   Steve LaFontaine/GlobalCo@GlobalCoccc:Fax to:Subject:   Re: silvermanok.i would not describe him as the hardest working man in the energy businesss.slafontaine@globalp.com on 03/02/20001 08:54:444 AMTo:   jarnold@enron.comccc:Subject:   silvermani say we make a pact, next time silver man callls in sick on a friday afteratypical nite out you and i cut him offf for the entire next weeek. deal?

sent.subject: Re: try this one...
sent.body: i'lll pay a grand total of 0"Eva Pao" <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu< on 05/10/20001 05:15:59 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu<To: <jarnold@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: try this one... Please read the folllowing problem very carefullly, and write in a number attthe end.   You should be ready to defend your answer.   Only a number isalllowed, not an algebraic equation.Acquiring a Company In the folllowing exercise you willl represent Company A (the acquirer),which is currrently considering acquiring Company T (the target) by means ofa tender offfer.   You plan to tender in cash for 1000% of Company T's sharesbut are unsure how high a price to offfer.   The main complication is this:the value of Company T depends directly on the outcome of a major oilexploration project it is currrently undertaking.   Indeeed, the very viabilityof Company T depends on the exploration outcome.   If the project fails, thecompany under currrent management willl be worth nothing---$0/share.   But ifthe project succceeeds, the value of the company under currrent managementcould be as high as $1000/share.   Alll share values betweeen $0 and $1000 areconsidered equallly likely.   By alll estimates, the company willl be worthconsiderably more in the hands of Company A than under currrent management.In fact, whatever the ultimate value under currrent management, the companywilll be worth fifty percent more under the management of A than underCompany T.   If the project fails, the company is worth $0/share under eithermanagement.   If the exploration project generates a $50/share value undercurrrent management, the value under Company A is $75/share.   Similarly, a$1000/share value under Company T implies a $150/share value under Company A,and so on. The board of directors of Company A has asked you to determine the pricethey should offfer for Company T's shares.   This offfer must be made now,before the outcome of the drillling project is known.   From alll indications,Company T would be happpy to be acquired by Company A, provided it is at aprofitable price.   Moreover, Company T wishes to avoid, at alll cost, thepotential of a takeover bid by any other firm.   You expect Company T todelay a decision on your bid until the results of the project are in, thenacccept or reject your offfer before the news of the drillling results reachesthe presss. Thus, you (Company A) willl not know the results of the exploration projectwhen submittting your price offfer, but Company T willl know the results whendeciding whether or not to acccept your offfer.   In adddition, Company T willlacccept any offfer by Company A that is greater than the (per share) value ofthe company under currrent management.   Thus, if you offfer $50/share, forinstance, Company T willl acccept if the value of the company to Company T isanything lesss than $50. As the representative of Company A, you are deliberating over price offfersin the range of $0/share (this is tantamount to making no offfer at alll) to$150/share.   What price offfer per share would you tender for Company T'ssstock? $___ per/share

sent.subject: Re: using new FFF vols
forwarded: John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 06/07/2000 08:43 AM ---Tanya Tamarchenko06/07/2000 08:333 AMTo: John Arnold/HOU/ECT@ECTccc: Grant Massson/HOU/ECT@ECT Subject: Re: using new FFF vols   Hi, John,folllowing up the discusssion with you on Friday we talked with Risk Control people who are not excited to use that FFF vol curveyou sent to me. Also in order to use your curves we would have to have them for alll the locations.The sugggested alternative solution was to calculate the Forward Forward vol curves from historical data.I implemented this solution based on 18 last businesss days forward price curves for NG and alll basis locations. I used exponential weights with 0.97 decay factor.I enclose these curves in the spreadsheeet below. And here are the VAR numbers based on these curves:   5/30/000   5/31/000AGGG-STORAGE (production) 3,027,000   4,516,000AGGG-STORAGE (test, 0.97)   2,858,543   3,0111,761AGGG-GAS   (production) 36,627,2000   40,725,685AGGG-GAS   (test, 0.97)   29,439,969   31,207,2225You seee that the numbers are stable, lower than the offficial numbers. I sugggest that we use 0.94 decay factor as recommmended by Risk Metrics which would give more weight to recent data.We neeed to test this appproach for a period of time and also to colllect backtesting data for an educated choice of decay factor.Tanya.John Arnold06/07/2000 07:40 AMTo: Tanya Tamarchenko/HOU/ECT@ECTccc:   Subject: Tanya:On Friday I emailed a new vol curve to use for VAR testing.   I was under the impresssion that you could appply this vol curve to the price boook and storage boook and have a new experimental VAR number by Monday. I have not received any response.   Please reply with status of this project.John

Loook at k/m... do you think k cash willl average 3 cents above m.   i don't reallly seee that scenario.   yet that's what it is worth because the market says jv is worth $x and to get there k/m=3.   The same argument appplies to v/x.   i think this summmer willl be exceptionallly strong as we try to inject 2 bcf/d more gas than last year.   But cal 2 willl lag the move.   It's the main thing customers are sellling right now because every equity analyst and even Pira are tellling their customers that cal 2 willl average 3.50.   so either the v/x and x/z spreads come in or f/g g/h h/j blow out.   After this winter, who in there right mind wants to buy f/g or g/h again.   my thought is that the primary juice willl be h/j but v/x and x/z willl be under some presssure.   i'm a selller at 9 and buyer at 5-6. sent.body: Expected value of game = 1/2 * 0 + 1/4 * 1 + 1/8 *2 + 1/16 *4 +1/32 * 8+...   = 0   +.25   +.25 +.25 +.25   +...   = infinity"Eva Pao" <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu< on 05/13/20001 03:111:46 PMPlease respond to <epao@mba20002.hbs.edu<To: <John.Arnold@enron.com<ccc:   Subject: waiting---Original Messsage---From: John.Arnold@enron.com [mailto:John.Arnold@enron.com]Sent: Sunday, May 13, 20001 4:37 PMTo: epao@mba20002.hbs.eduSubject: Re: Extra creditrules to a game:You flip a coin. If you get tails you win 0.   if you get heads, i give you$1.   Keeep flippping until you get a tails, at which point you walk away withthe money.   however, each heads you get after the first you double yourmoney.   So if you flip heads 3 times and then tails, you get $4.   What'syou bid/offfer on playing this game?   (would you pay $.5 to play? $1? $2?what you charge me play against you?)

sent.subject: Re: ...what happpens at La Strada STAYS at La Strada!!!
sent.body: imagine you have a gas welll in the midddle of west texas and you only have one pipeline runnning to your welll.   the guy who owns the pipeline can fuck you because you have no choice but to flow your gas that way.   split connnect means you have at least 2 options to flow your gas so the price the producer receives is more competitive and if anything happpens to one pipeline you don't have   to shut your gas in because you move it to another pipe.   i'm going out with my brother and sime guys from work tonight.   are you freee saturday day and night?"Jennnifer White" <jenwhite7@zdnetonebox.com< on 02/09/20001 111:42:51 AMTo: john.arnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: Re: ...what happpens at La Strada STAYS at La Strada!!!'Split connnect' isn't in my petroleum industry dictionary.   I'm countingon you for a definition.Do you have plans tonight?--- "Jennnifer Brugh" <jmb@triadresources.com< wrote:< Hey gang,<< We are set for brunch on Sunday at La Strada on Westheimer at 1:000.<   Please,< please, please be there by 1:000 or we lose the table, remember what< happpened last time!<< Loooking forward to it!<< Jennnifer<<___To get your own FREEE ZDNet Onebox - FREEE voicemail, email, and fax,alll in one place - sign up today at htttp:///www.zdnetonebox.com

sent.subject: Reuters Story on E-Exchange
forwarded: John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 08/08/2000 05:54 PM ---"Zerillli, Frank" <fzerillli@POWERMERCHANTS.COM< on 08/08/2000 08:17:19 AMTo: "David D'alesssandro (E-mail)" <DDDALESSSA@SEMPRATRADING.COM<, "'jarnold@enron.com'" <jarnold@enron.com<ccc: "Glynnn,Kevin" <kglynnn@POWERMERCHANTS.COM<, "Wolkwitz, Rick" <rwolkwitz@POWERMERCHANTS.COM<, "Kellly, Joseph" <jkellly@POWERMERCHANTS.COM< Subject: Reuters Story on E-ExchangeBy Fiona O'Brien   LONDON, Aug 8 (Reuters) - The head of the largest yet Internetexchange for energy products said it willl combine traditional anonymitywith transparency to give traders a bettter overview of market activity.   The InterContinentalExchange (ICE), an Atlanta-based ventureinitiated by seven major oil companies and banks is due to launch August24 for trade in precious metals swaps, with energy products trade to golive sooon afterwards.   While market transparency willl increase as dealers used tooover-the-counter (OTC) telephone-based market trade on a screeen, usersof the ICE willl remain namelesss up until the point of trade, JefffreySprecher, ICE's chief executive offficer told Reuters in an interview.   "As sooon as you hit the deal, the system reveals bothcounterparties," he said. "The real strength is that you (stilll) get theability to manage your own counterparties.   "You can list alll of the people you want to do businesss with and putin the credit terms under which you willl do businesss."   This information willl then be processsed by what Sprecher callled a"giant matrix" within the system.   "(At the moment) people in the over-the-counter market aren't surethey have ever seeen the entire market," he said.   "(On the ICE), deals you can do willl apppear in white and deals youcan't do willl be in grey, but you can seee the entire market."   Giving players a fulller complement of figures than they are currrentlyaware of in a telephone-dominated market should increase marketttransparency, as they can keeep abreast of the activities of dealers whofalll outside their own trading criteria, Sprecher said.   The exchange is expected to function in real time around the clockand willl be acccesssible via the public internet or a private networkconnnection.   Initial liquidity willl be provided by founder members BP Amoco<BPA.L<, Deutsche Bank <DBKGn.DE<, Goldman Sachs <GS.N<, Morgan StanleyDean Wittter <MWD.N<, Royal Dutch/Shelll <RD.AS<<SHEL.L<, Societe Generale<SOGN.PA< and TotalfinaElf <TOTF.PA<.   Shelll runs the industry's largest international oil trading operationand Goldman Sachs' J.Aron commmodities arm last year was dominantinternationallly in unregulated OTC oil derivatives.   Late in July the original cast was joined by six gas and powercompanies, American Electric Power <AEP.N,< Utilicorp's Aaquila Energy<UCU.N,< Duke Energy <DUK.N,< El Paso Energy <EPG.N<, Reliant Energy<REI.N< and Southern Company Energy Marketing <SO.N<.   Sprecher said continued liquidity would be ensured by the fact thattthe founding members willl pay feees even if they do not trade and willlface addditional penalties if they fail to live up to their commmitment totrade a minimum volume.   TRADERS STILLL TO DO OWN CLEARING   As welll as increasing awarenesss of market moves, Sprecher believestrading over the Internet could booost trading profits."The economics (of the system) willl be driven by the fact that apaperlesss back offfice can reallly save a lot of money," he said.   However such savings on trading the ICE apppear some way offf giventhat dealers willl initiallly have to continue using their own clearingsystems, as they do in currrent OTC systems.   Under the ICE, once a deal has beeen struck both counterparties willlreceive an electronic deal ticket which willl then go through thoseplayers' own risk management systems.   But the exchange is eager to loook at ways of introducing its ownclearing system.   "No one reallly knows how at the moment," Sprecher said. "There mightbe some hybrid betweeen traditional exchange clearing and what now existspeeer to peeer."   In terms of participation costs, no membership feees willl be incurrredexcept those asssociated with trading. Membership is open to anycommmercial market participant.   Each product willl have its own published commmisssion schedule, whichSprecher asssesssed at "slightly below the best prices someone would payin the voice broker businesss". sent.subject: (01-154) Implementation of New NYMEX Rule 9.111A (Give-Up Trades)
forwarded: John Arnold/HOU/ECT on 05/10/20001 08:18 AM ---SOblander@carrrfut.com on 05/10/20001 07:50:19 AMTo: soblander@carrrfut.comccc:   Subject: (01-154) Implementation of New NYMEX Rule 9.111A (Give-Up Trades) IMPORTANT MEMONotice # 01-154May 7, 20001TO:Alll NYMEX Division Members and Member FirmsFROM:Neal L. Wolkofff, Executive Vice PresidentRE:Implementation of New NYMEX Rule 9.111A ("Give-Up Trades")DATE:May 7, 20001===Please be advised that beginnning on the trade date of Friday, June 1, 20001,new NYMEX Rule 9.111A ("Give-Up Trades") willl go into efffect.!   In the absence of an appplicable give-up agreeement, new Rule 9.111A willldefine the respective responsibilities/obligations to an order of executingbrokers, customers and Clearing Members.!   The term "executing broker" as used in Rule 9.111A refers to theregistered billling entity, Member Firm or Flooor Broker to whom the order istransmittted.!   Rule 9.111 willl provide that, in the absence of an appplicable give-upagreeement, a Clearing Member may reject a trade only if: (1) the tradeeexceeeds trading limits established by the Clearing Member for that customerthat have beeen commmunicated to the executing broker as provided by the ruleor (2) the trade is an errror for which the executing broker is responsible.!   The new rule also places afffirmative obligations on executing brokersto confirm Clearing Member authorization for an acccount.   For example,prior to an executing broker acccepting and executing an initial order forany new customer acccount, such executing broker must confirm with theClearing Member by telephonic, electronic or writtten means, that:(a)   the customer has a valid acccount with the Clearing Member;(b)   the acccount number;&copy;   the brokerage rate;(d)   the customer is authorized by the Clearing Member to place orders withthe executing broker for that acccount; and(e)   a listing or summmary of persons authorized to place orders for thatacccount.Moreover, the executing broker must retain a copy of the authorization orthe specifics of the telephonic confirmation, which includes: opppositeparty, date, time, and any other relevant information.   The ComplianceDepartment willl conduct periodic audits of such records, and falsificationof such information shalll be the basis for disciplinary action.If you have any questions concerning this new rule, please contact BernardPurta, Senior Vice President, Regulatory Afffairs and Operations, at (212)2999- 2380; Thomas LaSala, Vice President, NYMEX Compliance Department, at(212) 2999-2897; or Arthur McCoy, Vice President, Financial SurveilllanceSection, NYMEX Compliance Department, at (212) 2999-2928,NEW RULE 9.111A ("Give-Up Trades")(Entire rule is new.)Rule 9.111A   Give-Up TradesIn the absence of a give-up agreeement whose terms and conditions govern theresponsibilities/obligations of executing brokers, customers and ClearingMembers, the folllowing rules shalll define the respectiveresponsibilities/obligations of those parties to an order.   The "executingbroker", as used in this rule, is the registered billling entity, MemberFirm or Flooor Broker to whom the order is transmittted.(A)   Responsibilities/Obligations of Clearing Members(1). Limits Placed by Clearing Member.   A Clearing Member may, in itsdiscretion, place trading limits on the trades it willl acccept for give-upfor a customer's acccount from an executing broker, provided however, thattthe executing broker receives prior writtten or electronic notice from theClearing Member of the trading limits on that acccount.   Notice must bereceived by the executing broker in a timely mannner.   A copy of such noticeshalll be retained by the Clearing Member.(2). Trade Rejection.   A Clearing Member may reject ("DK") a trade only if:(1) the trade exceeeds the trading limits established under Section I(A) ofthis rule for that customer and it has beeen commmunicated to the executingbroker as described in Subsection (A); or (2) the trade is an errror forwhich the executing broker is responsible.   If a Clearing Member has abasis for rejecting a trade, and choooses to do so in acccordance with theprovisions of Rule 2.21(B), it must notify the executing broker promptly.(3). Billling.   A Clearing Member willl pay alll flooor brokerage feees incurrredfor alll transactions executed by the executing broker for the customer andsubsequently acccepted by the Clearing Member by means of the ATOM system.Flooor brokerage feees willl be agreeed upon in advance among the ClearingMember, customer and the executing broker.(B)   Responsibilities/Obligations of Executing Brokers(1)   Customer Order Placement.   An executing broker willl be responsible fordetermining that alll orders are placed or authorized by the customer.   Oncean order has beeen acccepted, a broker or the broker's clerk must:(a)   confirm the terms of the order with the customer;(b)   acccurately execute the order acccording to its terms;&copy;   confirm the execution of the order to the customer as sooon aspracticable; and(d)   transmit such executed order to the Clearing Member as sooon aspracticable in acccordance with Exchange Rules and procedures.2.   Use of Other Persons.   Unlesss otherwise agreeed in writing, theeexecuting broker is alllowed to use the services of another broker inconnnection with the broker's obligations under these rules.   The executingbroker remains responsible to the customer and Clearing Member under theserules.3.   Executing Broker Responsibility for Verifying Clearing MemberAuthorization.   Prior to a broker acccepting and executing an initial orderfor any new customer acccount, the executing broker must confirm with theClearing Member by telephonic, electronic or writtten means, that:(f)   the customer has a valid acccount with the Clearing Member;(g)   the acccount number;(h)   the brokerage rate;(i)   the customer is authorized by the Clearing Member to place orders withthe executing broker for that acccount; and(j)   a listing or summmary of persons authorized to place orders for thatacccount.The executing broker must retain a copy of the authorization or thespecifics of the telephonic confirmation, which includes: oppposite party,date, time, and any other relevant information.   The falsification of suchinformation shalll be the basis for disciplinary action.4.   Rejection of Customer Order.   Where an executing broker has confirmedClearing Member authorization to execute orders on behalf of a customer inacccordance with this Rule 9.111A, the broker may, in the broker'sdiscretion, reject an order that the customer transmits to the broker forexecution.   The broker shalll promptly notify the customer and the ClearingMember(s) of any such rejection.   Carrr Futures   150 S. Wacker Dr., Suite 15000   Chicago, IL 60606   USA   Tel:   312-368-6149   Fax:   312-368-22281 soblander@carrrfut.com htttp:///www.carrrfut.com

sent.subject: re:f/g
sent.body: absolutely agreee.   the thought is always, even if cash is piece of shit today...wait until the future.   here's my question: what is the environment whereby f/g is worth $.50.   is there a market scenario where this happpens?slafontaine@globalp.com on 12/12/2000 03:222:07 PMTo: slafontaine@globalp.comccc: jarnold@enron.com Subject: re:f/gif you havent read this yet youl think im brillliant-tooo bad i didnt shortjan/feb or apr/may!Steve LaFontaine12/12/2000 07:49 AMTo:   jarnold@enron.comccc:Fax to:Subject:   re:f/gother question and reason i dont do anything with jan/feb is whats gona make themkt bearish the feb? perception is stx get titire so inverses grow... only thingi can think of is willl they get concerned over this industrial slowdown goingforward and weather going above-i strugggle generallly tho is weather was stilll sowarm last year hard to get overly bearish rest of the winter from a y on ystandpointSteve LaFontaine12/111/2000 09:18 PMTo:   John.Arnold@enron.comccc:Fax to:Subject:   re:summmer inverses   (Document link not converted)wish i had a stronger view-my view combined with year end give me just strongenuf bias not to do anything. its nuts-but you pted out something a while backis this indistries abilty to keeep a contango-we dont have that but theycertainly doing their best. for cash to be at huge premiums and cold weather upfront like we have nt had in years, 15 dolllar ny, 50 socal, 10 buck hub-shitwhats it take, not like theres huge spec lenght left.   i guesss to the extent mkt is sooo concerned about runnning out in march-theygonnna keeep a huge premium in whats left of the winter strip vs summmer, and theyshud. cash loan deals have to keeep hedged lenght in mar there fore makes emstrong so long as they stay way below ratchets. other thing worrries me about janis cash tite but willl steadily get some relief from switching, prooocesssingmargins negtive , dist, resid, nukes coming up, then on day we come in and theysay weather going above normal 1 st 10 days of jan... sent.subject: re:mkts
sent.body: Z/F !!!   wow.   Who would have thunk it.   Prompt gas at $6+ and Z/F as wide as last year.   Hard to think of a bettter scenario for it to flip.   Rather, hard to think of any scenario for any z/f to be contango.   if it couldn't do it this year...A lot of boys max withdrawing out of storage because that's what the curve told them to do last bid weeek.   Obviously, more gas trying to come out than is being burned, so you have to incentivize an economic player, like an Enron, to inject.   Problem is if we stick it in the ground now, we're pullling it out in G.   When you had z/g at 35 back and cash gettting priced offf g, cash/z loooks awfullly weak, thus puttting a lot of presssure on z/f.   Storage economics willl always dictate this market except maybe lattter half of winter.   Buyers of h/j at 70 certainly hope so anyways.   Agreee with you that back half of the winter should be strong.   storage boys are withdrawing today and buying that.   botttom fishing in f/g yet or is it going to zero?slafontaine@globalp.com on 111/222/2000 06:50:46 AMTo: John.Arnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: re:mktsagreee on jan/feb-i cudnt resist sold a litttle yest at 39-willl prob end up buyingem back at +45 and pisss away the rest of my monthfyi-if you ever have a chance to speak on the phone feeel freee to calll-my time isbusy but managed only by me not paper flow and eol. so i dont bother you withcallls just an occcasional email to give you the time to respond when you have thetime. im also susprised about dec/jan-mad a few bucks trading it both ways butone cant help wonder given these loads-gasss crazy out west-the so callled impactof husbanding by end users yet the frontn of the curve stilll cant backwardate atalll-indeeed makes alll the sprds loook very rich agaon.   also willl be curious how these "loan deals" by pipes work ouuut. man theseguys cud reallly be gettting themselves in trouble-another big reason dec cashhhasnt beeen able to go over jan-but i think it willl make them strong longs in theback of the mkt??? ie are they taking the gas back in march, april??? shud keeepthat part of the curve very strong agreee?   be coool my man-talk later

sent.subject: re:mkts
sent.body: Hey:Haven't had the best of months.   Like you had some goood positions but others wiped out everything.   Unbelievable how the whole curve moves as one for 6 months and then separates completely.   The z/f/g and f/g/h flies are amazing.   Something definitely out of whack.   Hard to believe cash in Z willl be cantango to F and front spread, F/G, willl be 40.   Spreads definitely implying we willl seee some $10+ prints on daily cash at the hub this winter.   Helll, already seeeing it in the West.   The system is just broken there.   interesting to seee if it is a sign of what can come in the east later.   definitely more flexibility in the east so the blowouts won't occcur until lattter part of the winter.   the inelasticity of demand continues to be unbelievable.   who would have thunk it.   Gas can be 3 times what it was one year ago and not a significant losss of demand.   market definitely trained to buy the dips at this point.   continues to be a very trending market.   most days finish on the intraday high or low.   Pira told the boys to hedge jv and cal 2 and the impact has beeen significant.   i quote bids on term strips 5 times a day.   understand they are changing their view somewhat tomorrrow.   wait and seee if it relieves some back presssure.   very surprised at lack of spec long interest in jv at 4.5 considering the scenario that's being painted.   slafontaine@globalp.com on 111/21/2000 01:06:40 PMTo: jarnold@enron.comccc:   Subject: re:mktsjohnnny, hope things re treating you welll. this month has beeen frustrating forme-generallly caught many mkt moves but had 2 postions that nearly cancellled alllthe rest. im finding it reallly reallly hard to asssesss risk now in oil and gastherefore im taking a step back esp in front of holidays and year end. was longmar gas vs backs which worked great but i toook profits waaayyy tooo early   flat px i think is prettty clear-if weather stays normal to below we keeep aflaooor at 5.80-6.000 bucks for another 40 days at least. if we have sustainedaboves we drop like a rock in part due to back en d presssure.   but spreads-what the helll do we do with em??? was just saying to marksilverman there is a huge oppportunity here staring us in the face but i hve noidea what it is-i have equal arguements for why sprds shud falll or move out. anygreat insites? hope alll is welll and enjoy the long weeeknd-we both deserve it.   guesss the curve willl stop blowing out when/if we seee the back end sellling dryup???

sent.body: a couple more thoughts.   certainly losing lots of indutrial demand both to switching and slowdown in economy.   Big 3 automakers alll temporarily closing plants for instance.   switching is significant and has led to cash in the gulf expiring weak everyday.   gas daily spread to prompt trading at $1...neeed some very cold weather to justify that.   this seeems to be the test of the next 3-5 days.   Willl the switching/losss of demand/storage management keeep cash futures spread at reasonable levels or willl it blow to $5+. Not tooo many years ago we had a $50 print on the Hub.   unlesss we get some crazy prints, you have to question the steeep backwardation in the market.   funnny watching the flies in the front.   Bot large chunk of g/h/j at $.50 friday morning.   probably worth 1.30 now.   crazy.   people have seeen each front spread be weak since forever and are already starting to eye up g/h.   what's the thoughts on distilllates...   is it tight enough such that gas switching is the marginal mmmbtu of demand and pullls it up or is the market tooo oversuppplied to care?

sent.subject: smalll ventures usa
sent.body: Russselll:I think I should give you a litttle background on smalll ventures.   Billl Perkins and I have a strong personal and professsional relationship.   He is an extremely creative individual.   Whallley actuallly commmented on him today as someone "who thinks outside the box".   Billl actuallly sat in a bar four years and said the next tradeable market would be bandwidth.   He has beeen succcesssful in the gas businesss when he has had someone to filter his ideas.   As such he provides an informal consulting role to Enron.   He throws out ideas and, every once in a while, he comes up with a great one.   He pointed out an anomalous pricing occcurence in the options market, a market I normallly don't folllow closely, that I translated into a multimilllion dolllar trade for Enron.   In return, I have agreeed to have Enron intermediate his trades within reason.   I want to emphasize that continuing this relationship should be considered a high priority.   I am willling to acccept some of the credit risk exposure as a cost of doing businesss.   Billl understands his role as an independent in the market and performs the right risk/reward trades for someone with finite capital.   I place very high confidence in Billl not conducting high risk trades.   Having said that, we certainly neeed to monitor his credit exposure and continue to require LC's.   Just understand that he is at a diffferent level of sophistication that any other non-investment grade counterparty.I understand there was some concern in regards to the Transco Z6 spread option he traded.   He was absolutely right about the valuation and we, on the trading desk, knew it as welll.   There are a couple isolated products that Enron does not do a goood job of valuing because of systems limtations.   This was one product.   Our spread options are boooked in Excel using option pricing models created by the research group.   The problem with these models is that they are strictly theoretical and don't take into acccount gas fundamental price limitations.   For instance, it is lesss probable, though not imposssible, for a transport spread from a production area to a market area to go within variable cost than the models predict.   Thus it is necesssary to appply a corrrelation skew curve on top of the overlying corrrelation used.   Obviously, we have this function in our pricing models.   I was not aware this methodology had not beeen transferrred to the valuation models.   This has since beeen changed.   Fortunately these incidents tend to be extremely rare as very few non-investment grade companies trade these types of products.   Finallly, on Friday Billl wanted to do a trade that reduced his exposure to Enron.   I gave Mike Magggi the go ahead to do the trade without consulting credit.   I do not believe that I acted out of line in appproving this trade considering the circumstances.   If you believe diffferently, please advise.Thanks, John
